Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2011 07:36PM konakat wrote: CGA -- I am so very sorry for your dear friend.  It does sound like she's in bad shape.  I can understand her husband wanting to give chemo a try -- he doesn't want to lose his wife.  I don't know if she will get help with the chemo if her body is so sick.  There does come a time when we either run out of chemos to try, or are just too sick to keep trying -- it's a hard place to be, making that decision that enough's enough and to start hospice care. As for time, who knows. I have been warned that the cancer can sneak up on you and take you fast.  There's no hard and fast rule. What does your friend want to do?  The best thing would be that everyone supports her choice, even if it's not what anyone else thinks is the best choice for her.  Her onc and even better a social worker at the hospital should have a good heart-to-heart with her and her husband.  If there really isn't much they can do perhaps the best thing would be for your friend talk to a hospice.  I have never heard a negative thing about hospice care.  A few of the women here are in hospice care and cannot say enough good things about the nurses, etc. I know my post is all wishy-washy but every patient has a different experience.  The only thing I can say for certainty is that whatever your friend decides, give her 100% of your support, which I know you will do.  Again, I am so sorry that your friend, her family and you are having to go through this.  It is so sad.  You are a good friend.  Lots of hugs, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Jun 17, 2010 04:27PM konakat wrote: Could it be your platelets? They're need for clotting the blood.  If you platelets are really low you sometimes bruise more easily.  If they get below 10 you may be given a platelet transfusion.  Mine got really low (in the teens) when I was on Gemzar but no transfusion, just kept decreasing the dose of the chemo.

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2011 07:14PM - edited Apr 12, 2011 07:17PM by konakat Haven't thought of a tagline yet -- but for sure it will indicate how things are going!  CT Scan next week (forgot when, gotta check), results Apr 26 (in Canuckland many companies and organizations, including hospitals (fewer services like at Christmas, Thanksgiving), have Good Friday and Easter Monday off).  Grrrrr.  Making me wait.  Grr. I'll be decapitating chocolate bunnies all that weekend! Oooh, I had a new low level from my labs today.  First, the usual suspects continue to be high or low.  Platelets were very low but I was approved for chemo anyway (68 when should be should be 150-450, at least 100 for chemo -- but I guess my skulls bandana makes me look like an ass-kicker that can handle it!  ).  ALP still high (320, which is good for me, but should be 50-136) and creeping up but still not 1200 like last summer!  So a big yawnarama there too. The weird new one was magnesium!!  I got an Mg IV infusion and will get one again with the next chemo.  I found out that Mg is important for absorbing calcium and preventing osteoporosis (good grief, I drink milk like a calf and take calcium and Vit D - I hope I`m not peeing it all out!!).  Elevated ALP can be caused by both liver mets and sometimes extensive bone mets.  Huh and Hmmmmm.  And my bones have been extra achy.  Hmmmm again.  At my crappy level an IV infusion is needed but my nurse mentioned that high fiber cereals and chocolate are rich in Mg!!!  Coffee too!!!!!  OK, can we say chocolate milk on my cereal tomorrow!  Assuming my brain boogers are gone, things are looking good for today.  Yah, all things in perspective.  Still worried about CT next week but I`ll deal with it then. Thanks for dropping by!!!

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2011 03:42PM konakat wrote: Hi Katie, This happened to me a lot.  Sometimes my WBC were low, then my platelets (a lot), once my hemoglobin.  So I'd miss my treatment and have to wait until the next cycle.  I hated not getting my chemo.  Sometimes I begged for it (didn't help)!  However, even missing a treatment about every second month, Navelbine and Carbo still beat back my liver, bone and lungs mets. My onc said that since I've been on chemo for so long my body was getting worn out.  That's why my labs were often bad.  But I kept trudging along and got results.  I hope with all my might that you will too.  And, I don't think it's too bad to miss the occasional treatment -- your body gets a chance to rest up for the next one.

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2009 05:00AM konakat wrote: Hi Kirby -- I know how you feel.  It's so strange, to have mets but not feel sick.  Cancer's in our bones and liver, how can I just carry on as if it wasn't there?  Last year I had to convince a co-worker that I had mets and was getting chemo -- she thought I was teasing.  It wasn't until I got a bad scan this spring that the mets really hit me -- and I've had it for over 2 years!  I've forced myself to come to terms with it -- to think about my life, what I want to do before it's too late.  I hope I have a long time, but sometimes complications come up so fast it's scary.  I don't have any advice, I only wanted to say that I've felt the same way as you. Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2011 02:48PM konakat wrote: Ooooh, forget Robert Downey Jr. I ended up in the arms of Benoit the cute rad tech!  It was so embarrassing.  I had one of my dizzy spells and down I went in the hallway.  Everyone in the waiting room saw.  I think I was only out for a few seconds (first time that happened), poor Benoit was holding my head off the floor and a nurse was there asking if I was alright, where I was (took a bit to spit out what I wanted to say), I did get my name right though. But it's no biggie -- I've been falling down for about a year.  I've gotten quite good at slithering down walls in my apartment.  It happened once last summer at Sharon50's -- she tried to catch me, it was hilarious for me, scary for Sharon. There's an absolutely adorable older lady at rads, probably about 80-ish.  She overheard me mention to the nurse that today was Robert Downey Jr day.  When I said tomorrow is Johnny Depp day the sweet lady said ooooooh, I'll take him! So, two, two zaps done!  Mouhouhahahahahahaaaaa!! I have Dr. Delish (rad onc) tomorrow (mental note: fall forward into his lap) and zapping at noon. Thanks for all the posts -- you really cheer me up!!!!!

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2011 10:04AM konakat wrote: THREE DONE!!!! No Benoit today but I saw Dr. Delish.  I forgot to swoon into his lap, accidentally grabbing his zipper in my teeth.  I was too intoxicated by his gorgeous blue-grey eyes instead. <sigh...> He wasn't concerned about my passing out and falling -- I didn't think I passed out, only well, I guess I did...  Since I've been dizzy and falling for quite a while it's not likely from the rads and brain.  AND, he gave me the bad news that I probably won't get goofy!!  What a disappointment -- I was all geared up for some fun.  He said he can't guarantee it so there's hope.  But then, I may be able to drive again in time.  I feel fine now and could drive but I won't, just in case. Poor Bubba -- maybe he has a nice personality.  Tomorrow is Colin Farrell day!  Love those bad boys!  Maybe next week can be time travel week and I can play with the hunks posted above.  I have to add Jim Morrison to the list!!!  My last day's fantasy will be Steven Tyler -- he'd be a fun guy to play with! Congratulations on your new grandbaby Barbe!  The world can never have too many Georges!! Now to drool over some Colin Farrell pics.

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2009 03:56AM - edited Jul 30, 2009 04:00AM by konakat Depending on where your lumpectomy is, this might work.  Mine is on the outer, lower area.  So I get those bras that have the extra padding that you can remove from pockets in the cup.  So I take the one from the "good" boob cup and put it in the "bad" boob cup to double the padding there.  It helps compensate when I wear something a bit close fitting.  It's not perfect, but I can still use my old bras. Edited:  for spelling.  For some reason my chemo brain has problems with homonyms (sp?) -- where, wear...
Posts.Title: buying bras post lumpectomy dragongal susan_CNY

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2011 10:30AM konakat wrote: I've been dizzy for over a year -- seems to be from the chemo wearing me out.  It happened about 2 years ago when Taxol was getting a bit too toxic for me.  The nurses think it's from blood pressure issues -- if I leap up out of a sitting position too quickly and trot off somewhere I get dizzy.  So far the rads have only caused fatigue and a sore throat.  The sore throat is due to the bonus zapping of my first few vertebae that have mets in the marrow.  Yuck.  But my neck is not as sore anymore so that's good.  The rads have been very gentle on me.  Quite a surprise. Re. Brad:  The only thing I can find wrong with Brad is his horrible taste in women!  I would have been much better for him...

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 12:25PM konakat wrote: Anyone can ask me anything, don't be shy. One of the rad techs told me that my head will feel prickly when my hair is about to drop, just like it feels with chemo.  Today the top of my head feels prickly but when I tug on my hair nothing falls out.  It's supposed to start to grow in after about 2 months. Kinda slow -- mine grew in quickly even when I was still on the chemo that made it fall out.  I've read that it can come in blotchy too -- yah, like I want to look like I have mange!! I'll start wearing my black wig and pretend I'm Uma Thurman from Pulp Fiction.  Maybe add a beret and pretend I'm a French spy.  Ooo-la-la! I'm going to experiment with painkillers again this weekend.  I want to be sure that Tylenol with codeine and Morphine don't help so I can tell McDreamykins.  My platelets are probably in the pisser with all the Ibuprofen I've been taking. Time to nap...

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2011 03:20PM konakat wrote: I'm feeling a bit better.  I've been having fun -- between yesterday evening and right now I've yanked out about 90% of my hair!!  It is entertaining, with each yank I wonder if it will be a few hairs or a big gob of them. It was wonderful seeing McDreamy.  He said if my throat is better by the weekend we'll go ahead with chemo on Tuesday.  If not, postpone it a week.  It will be the same ol' chemo -- Navelbine, Carboplatin, and Zometa.  Since it has been working, except for the brain boogers, we might as well stick with it.  I'm also getting a CT to see if my liver, etc. has run amok the past month or so.  And an echocardiogram to see how my heart's doing too. I also saw Dr. Delish and he gave me a prescription for this goop that will coat my throat and take away the pain.  It works!  Yay!! So, the drama is over, for now.  I can't wait until June to see if the rads worked.  If it didn't get all the lesions I'm pretty well toast -- they're too small to cyberknife.  But that's OK.  I've assumed I've been toast for quite a while and am sort of used to the idea. Thanks for hanging around with me.  You've definitely made it a lot easier to get through.

I clipped what was left of my hair.  Now I only need to find my lint roller.  Lint roller?  Yes, indeedie -- the one of the best tips I ever got here.  When the clipped itty bitty hairs fall out it's easy to lint roll them right off your head instead of letting them fall where ever and be itchy.  Brush your teeth, lint roll your head and you're ready to face the day!

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2011 10:18PM konakat wrote: Bah.  I'm having a hard time emotionally.  The past couple of weeks I have been pondering when I should just stop trying to keep going.  I do have good days and am somewhat happy but then I sink and feel like a fraud saying that I can do this, being encouraging when it seems that I can't do this anymore. Now this is creepy dream stuff.  Creepy, erotic, strange.  Be forewarned!!  It's a long post but you might find it interesting.  Or not. What's weird is that I've always has big epic dreams, many part of a repertoire that replay once and a while.  Big sci-fi or fantasy productions that make Hollywood blockbusters seem like documentary shorts.  When I was little I'd call them movies in my head.  I'm always the leader, going against adversaries like monsters, aliens, and bad people.  I always get away, lead my followers to beautiful pastures, the hero, win.  In one dream I often have I have this cool pod I can fly in.  Zoom! Anyway...lately I'm not the leader, or am crappy at it.  Yesterday I dreamed I was part of a group to be culled by the invaders but had a chance to get away by demonstrating my value.  I had to go pee and missed out on my chance.  The invadors were impressed by my ability to pee though.  But not impressed enough to give me a chance and let me try to impress in some other way.  We were all made of clay and tornados were coming -- freaky eh? Anyway, I crawled into bed earlier today and to hopefully avoid these dreams I fantasized about being on a big foam mattress, floating off a beach.  There was a gorgeous man in white linen pants and shirt, long black dreadlocks, floating near me in a kayak who would slowly pull me closer to shore if I drifted out too far.  He'd spray on sunscreen or give me a sip of water when I needed it.  He was so quiet, he just knew when and what he was to do.  I seldom completely woke from my dozing.  I was safe, comforted, and content.  Sometimes I'd feel him lying beside me, holding my hand, sometimes dozing with his hand resting on my bare belly (yes, I'm nude, with all my flaws exposed).  He smelled so crisp and clean, like linen and salt air. We never spoke. Towards the end of the day we headed back to our one-room cottage.  White cotton drapes billowing into the room, palm leaf fan on the ceiling keeping us cool as we dozed on this so soft bed.  I woke and it was night time but daylight was out.  Strange.  Then my cats Chloe and Ursula (they're not alive anymore) came padding into the room.  They beckoned towards me, that look of "are you going to fill the catfood dish, come on!"  They looked at me and started towards the big window.  My beautiful cats.  I rose to start following them, after one or two steps I disappeared with them. Dream over.  At some point I must have been asleep since it felt like I woke up when I left with Chloe and Ursula.  I was so very happy to be with my cats but so sad that I was with this guy when I died instead of my Mom.

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2011 10:23AM konakat wrote: All the spirituality stuff in the beach dream is freaking me out.  I'm counting on becoming fertilizer with my cats and literally pushing up daisies (mix my ashes with theirs, toss around outside, dig a hole and dump us in -- Mom's still not keen on mixing us into the soil of her flower gardens yet...) It's funny about my epic hero dreams.  I've never been a leader, the one who makes decisions in real life.  I just dream about what I wish I was.  The beach dream was the most significant dream I've ever had though.  I just had to write it down or I would have burst.  Thanks for reading it and not thinking I'm too wackydoodles.  Or being polite and not letting on that you do.  Heehee.

Posts.Content: May 16, 2010 07:06PM konakat wrote: I have to reiterate what Darlene said -- it's not true that a brain lesion has to be 1cm or more to treat.  Mine was 5mm (or was it 6mm? Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2009 09:38AM konakat wrote: Hi Grace -- I think Vilma (activern) gives good advice.  Being an RN and one of us I absolutely trust her opinion.  Putting off the chemo won't be too bad.  We've all had to postpone treatment (myself included) and it is frustrating an disappointing but it's for the best.  If your onc wants you to sign a waiver the clot issue is serious and risky.  Better to take care of the clot first and then get back on chemo.  Also, see your regular doc as soon as you can and get a referral to a hematologist as Vilma suggested.  Hang in there Grace, I know it's hard, but you'll get through this. Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2007 04:34AM konakat wrote: Hi Kelolo.  I think we all had these awful feeling, crying, feeling "ripped off" getting this disease.  I was so distraught about my hair I argued with my oncologist about chemo -- do I really need it?  Yes, I was, at least for a moment, more worried about my hair than having cancer. Yes, it is very overwhelming.  I made a list of questions for my doc -- took a few days writing them.  He/she is obliged to answer them, and very happy to explain things if he/she is a decent doc and caring person. What I found that helped get over the feeling helpless and out of control was to finally get my treatment nailed down and the schedule set.  Having that action plan to beat this cancer really helped.  You will feel in control and feel ha -- I'm gonna defeat this thing.  You are the general leading the war -- it makes you feel strong.  Yes, there are side effects but drugs to help.  And a bonus, when your hair starts growing in it is so soft!!  I sit watching TV rubbing my head -- it feels soooo good!! Yes, you feel like hell right now and you have every right to do so!!!!  Once you get going with your treatment you will feel more in control.  And visit this website often -- the women here are great.  Any time I feel a weird side effect or wonder about something I always find others here who are or have experienced the same thing and share some good tips and information. I wish you all the best --

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2011 08:54PM - edited Feb 16, 2011 08:55PM by konakat I was wondering if doing some rads on your bones will help rebuild them.  And with a few more weeks off chemo all your bloodwork will get within the acceptable levels for a trial.  Can your onc re-try some of the chemos you had at the beginning in case they might work again?  The BC might have mutated again and become susceptable to some chemos previously tried.   Also, if you were responsive to AIs, I have read several times that by taking Estrogen you can re-boot your system so AIs work again. I do hope you find some solutions soon.  Hugs, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2009 02:10PM konakat wrote: Hi Katie, I'm sorry about your Mom.  Chemo and the shots can be hard, really zap your energy, and give you a lot of aches.  It can take a quite few months after chemo is finished to regain your strength back and also can take longer depending on the extent of the mets.  What I think you should do is try to go to one of the chemo appts with your Mom and talk to the oncologist or one of the nurses -- tell her your concerns and ask what you and your Mom can expect for her recovery.  Good luck, and hugs for your Mom. Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2010 10:28AM konakat wrote: Hi Connie -- Sorry you had to join "Club Mets", but welcome.  So far I've had it relatively easy with my mets (dx-ed with liver from the get-go, almost 3 years ago; still in liver and now bones).  I say relatively easy in that I don't have much pain from my bone mets, worked through my treatments, pretty well live a normal life.  The fatigue sucks.  Only recently I've decided to go on disability because I'm just fed up, tired, my back is getting a bit painful, and my prognosis sucks so I want to enjoy life. For me, the worst is the emotional ups and downs.  I occasionally have big "why me" pity parties.  But I get through them.  It's very hard when you get a scan showing progression and that the chemo's stopped working.  Again, I get through the shock and sadness and go on to the next chemo and kick the cancer back. You can live a very normal life.  Some have a terrible time, others not.  What I try to do is acknowledge that cancer has screwed up part of my life but not let it screw up all of my life.  If you do, it wins.  Like Fitz says, you try not to live in cancer land.  It doesn't define who you are. In other words, you are not Connie with cancer, you are Connie.  And, I probably would be a basket case if it weren't for the support of the women here.  They're the best.  Hugs, Elizabeth xoxoxoooo

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 12:43AM konakat wrote: Gee, I'm feeling not bitchy at all.  I'm glad I'm not alone.  Thanks! I started this thread/question because I have come to a few realizations and was worried that I was being too harsh, or expecting too much.  Here's what's up: I've been traipsing along, la-dee-la-la-la-la, OK chemo will get this under control, I'll be one out of the 4 or 5 who makes it to 5 years, maybe not 10, 8 years sounds like a good number.  You can get a lot done in 8 years! OK, I'm mixing metaphors, but while traipsing along, I've had my head in the sand, butt straight up in the air with regards to Stage IV.  Each time one of our dear sisters takes a turn for the worse, I think that can't be right, she must be well. Or if someone dies, no, I want her back right now!  This is wrong and not happening. Good stuff does happen, but so does bad stuff, all too often. With each test I have, I lie to myself that I expect the worst to lessen the blow of a bad scan, but secretly I hope for and expect the best, only to be disappointed.  My onc and I are no longer talking NED.  OK, so what do I need to do to catch the eye of the d*mn stable boy?  Hey!  I'll put out, forget the dinner and dance, I'll go right for a roll in the hay if that will work. (On another thread we were discussing depression and humour -- this is an attempt at humour as a coping mechanism -- sorry for the side bar here...). So, haven't I been stupid.  In denial (on the most beautiful barge....).  I've started to realize these past few months that holy crap, this Stage IV is some serious sh*t!  I've always known it was serious, but now I know.   This is so scary, my mind is spinning.  It's like the taxi cab is at the door and I haven't started packing yet!  I need more time!!  Whew!  Sorry about that!  Yes, I can live a good life, have fun, have hope, feel joy (for example, next week I'm going to the ocean and plan on splashing around in the water like a total idiot and not care if I look silly).  But my long winded point is, regardless of how good, fair, or bad we're doing, this Stage IV is some very serious sh*t.  It can be hard to get your mind wrapped around it, even for a metster. So tread with care, I usually meow, sometimes I might growl (but with a smile, and I really do care about you, even if I do growl!) Off to bed (I can't believe it took me 1.5 hours to write this!!).  Thanks to anyone that took the time to read this.
Posts.Title: Advice for metsters konakat RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2009 05:01PM - edited Aug 23, 2009 05:31PM by konakat I do think Nash and Barbe can provide valuable contributions -- they have experiences that they can share that are appropriate to some Stage IV discussions.  For example, Barbe has posted some very thoughful support and advice to our friend Cyn. And I think both Barbe and Nash are thoughtful enough to know when to not post.  Like Fitz says, the pity, prayer, swoop in, etc. posts don't help.  I think they only serve the ones posting them -- to make them feel good that they are so grand and caring as to pity us.  Sorry, it may not be your intent, but often that's how it is perceived.   However, if it is a thread explicitly asking for prayers and best wishes, it's another thing, if it's done with thought for the recipient. Yes, slippery it is.  I guess, if it really isn't going to help someone, don't bother.  Fitz mentioned this on another thread, but I'll repeat it, we do already know that you care.  Thank-you. Pitanga has made a good point about when you are "just diagnosed" and when you are past that.  My thoughts are that the "just diagnosed" is that horrible time when there is the flurry of thoughts and emotions that need to be expressed when first diagnosed with mets. Once you've lived through that phase, it is hard to re-live it over and over through others in that phase.  I'm sorry if that sounds harsh new mets sisters, but I hope you'll understand.  The Stage IV "just diagnosed" forum serves a good purpose, just like the non-staged "just diagnosed" forum.  I see the Stage IV forum as the time when we say "OK, I've got mets, now let's deal with it."  That is what bonds all mets sisters together, each in our different boat but heading the same way.  As a little side note to Pitanga -- I can empathize -- I'm away from my family and country -- but, not as far as you are.  And I too am struggling with finding a job, having little money, and getting chemo at the same time.  It is a nightmare.  It's a lot to shoulder at one time. Edit to tweak grammar and to add:  When it comes to the Palliative forum -- I do believe that is "sacred ground".  And that is the intent of the Moderators.

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2009 01:19PM - edited Aug 22, 2009 01:35PM by konakat I don't often, but sometimes, post on the non-Stage IV threads.  The most recent was on the chemo thread where someone was posting a bunch of crap that chemo doesn't work and apparently was scaring the heck out of some newbies.  I directed her to the American Cancer Society for info, and some other places.  I just hate it when bad info makes it's rounds. So many times I see someone on the Just Diagnosed thread that is scared and I want to reach out to her but don't -- the last thing I think she wants to see is a Stage IV person.  Re. thoughtless people -- I have a girlfriend who had a cancer scare -- it was benign.  But she still refers to the both of us as survivors.  Ahem....  I take it as an insult to every woman, Stage 0 - IV for her to call herself a survivor!  And I'm not really a survivor, I'm living with it.  Heather -- It's rum cake.  I don't really like it but it was some else's birthday.  I like the good old fashioned vanilla cakes with the huge icing roses that you get at the grocery store.  But then, if something has icing on it I will stick a fork in it eat it! Re. breast cancer awareness booths.  Whenever I'm asked for a donation and I just say I've already offered my body for clinical trials. That's my donation.  I was very lucky, I found this site just a few weeks after dx.  It's been a life saver.  I have my snits once in a while, jaw-dropping experiences with some posts, but overall, I'm so grateful to have this site.  Other women who understand and listen. I'm amazed and delighted by the positive feedback on this thread!  At first I winced before clicking it in my favourites.  No one has said I'm bitchy yet but I'm sure some think I am.  BTW -- frequent edits bec I keep thinking of something else as soon as I click submit.  Like this one:  It's so cool to see some women posting here that I haven't seen around for a while!  Very nice to see you again!!
Posts.Title: Advice for metsters konakat RobinWendy

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2009 01:21PM konakat wrote: Heather -- I read up on scleroderma -- and what an ordeal you've had (huge understatement) -- I cannot express my feelings without sounding sappy or dorky.  Then BC on top of it. I especially like your #4 -- something to look forward to.  All too often my glass is half empty with stuff that tastes awful.  It's that curiousity of what's around the corner that keeps me going.  Something to look forward to.  And the kindness and friends I have found here.  Meanness or flippant remarks in any context/discussion is so not nice.

Posts.Content: konakat wrote: Am I just being b*tchy or over-sensitive?  I really resent early stage women giving advice to Stage IV/Palliative women (or their family) on how to proceed with their treatment.  I've seen this from women whom I think are lovely, kind women on this site, but it just irks me.  I think it's a whole different ball game once you are Stage IV/Palliative and unless you're in the game you really don't get what it's like.  I don't think anyone has a clue how I feel (or any Stage IV woman) or can give meaningful advice re. Stage IV/Palliative issues except for other Stage IV sisters.  Am I being b*tchy, or are my feeling justified? Sometimes I just don't know... My 2AM edit:  Hey - insomnia's good for something.  I really shouldn't have clomped all non-metsters together.  There have been some thoughtful comments, acknowledging the gravity (severity? scariness? not sure what word to use) of the Stage IV existence by some non-metsters -- my apologies to them.  I guess it's just the almost off-the-cuff rah-rah comments that bug me.  Or those that swoop in to say how strong we are and how much they wish we get better -- makes me feel like an exhibit at a zoo -- oooh, look at the stage IV lady...  I've posted more below on this.... Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Elizabeth's Mets: Liver, bones, brain (yuck), and lungs (more yuck). Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2009 11:57AM konakat wrote: Hi Abby.  I had some wonky things happen with my taxol -- ups and downs on whether it was working.  Even though it seemed to be working, the wonkiness (on too long, getting toxic, falling down, irregular results...) lead my onc to stop taxol and switch to another chemo (Gemzar) so see if we get more consistent results.  Is this an option for you, to try a different chemo?  Re TM -- my onc only does them at the beginning of a new tx cycle.  They haven't been reliable for me because they were often in the normal range when I was popping lesions all over my liver.  I guess this just goes to show how crazy and unpredicatable this f*ckin' cancer is. Perhaps you can ask your onc about trying another chemo which might work better for you -- easier on your general health and kick cancer butt.  And a second opinion is always a good thing. Please let us know how it goes, what you decide.  And, of course, big monster hugs for you, lots of them.  Elizabeth xox

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2009 11:22AM konakat wrote: Pamela and Lilith of course your're welcome to post your comments.  And Barbe -- you'll never be a pollyanna -- you shoot straight from the hip -- you're the best!!!  Re. visiting the boards:  Before it was confirmed I was stage IV, I would sometimes come to peek in the Stage IV and Palliative boards -- wondering what was what -- just like some of you said, just in case, I wanted to have some knowledge.  Nothing wrong with that.  And really, there's nothing to oooh, and awww about someone being Stage IV, no heroic strength or iron will -- you just do what you gotta do.  It's a very strange place to be -- I'm aware of living and dying at the same time.  But I do get a lot of hope from the women here.  There's always that.  I love the good news celebrations -- I do a Snoopy dance for those! Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2010 06:32PM konakat wrote: Good to hear that you're feeling better Brenda.  I didn't drink enough fluids at first and found it make a big difference when I started drinking a few more glasses of water and kept a glass beside me to sip when I was lolling, watching TV, etc.  I also tried to tough it out with the side effects.  I eventually got over that too -- why feel like crap if you don't have to?  You're on a hard chemo but a very, very good chemo -- you'll do great.  And about the mean co-worker -- walk away and ignore her -- you are a much better person that she can ever dream of being.  Have a great weekend, Elizabeth
Posts.Title: Starting to feel human again!!! bkglenn50 bkglenn50

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2010 01:57PM konakat wrote: Hi Michelle -- there's a woman here called Chainsawz who has had lesions in her brain.  And she's doing wonderfully -- still working, kicking major butt.  When she sees your post she'll come say hi.  And now worries about yourself too.  The mention of assymetry is that sometimes cancer grows in an odd shape.  But hang on until you get the biopsy -- it could a number of things that aren't BC.  Take care, Elizabeth
Posts.Title: Hello Friends Again - I need your help mimi1030 tami444

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2009 10:45AM konakat wrote: Check Expedia and Travelocity for rooms.  Perhaps make this a gift to youself and splurge on a suite at a hotel downtown.  Or, if you can't find a decent place in Boston try looking just outside the city and rent a car.  Parking is expensive downtown but the cost will probably work out the same, probably less, if you stay and drive in from the burbs -- Woburn and Burlington are relatively close and have quite a few decent hotels. Do a search at the Holiday Inn, Ramada, Marriott, Sheraton websites... If you do get a hotel, even just 20 miles outside Boston, plan for a 1 - 1.5 hour drive it, rush hour is clogged with people commuting in from the burbs and NH, RI, CT. If you are within a driveable distance to Boston, park at the Alewife subway station for example, (Arlington, $7/day) and you can easily take the train in.  Here's a link to the subway info: http://www.mbta.com/ . Elizabeth
Posts.Title: MBCN conference in Boston Fitztwins konakat

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2009 09:39AM konakat wrote: I did carbo, taxol, herceptin, and zometa.  Taxol sucks.  Carbo is gentler in that there's no hair loss -- I'd certainly give carbo a try and keep my hair!!!  I too feel so much better and relaxed when a new treatment plan is made.  I can't wait to see my onc tomorrow to get back on the chemo bandwagon!  BTW -- I've been on Gemzar and it is gentle too, no hair loss, minimal SEs (except low platelets).  I wish all chemos were like this!!

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2010 07:30AM - edited Jan 26, 2010 07:31AM by konakat Hi Katie -- what worked for me was spicy, aromatic foods, but you have to love them in the first place. The flavour and smell of Thai and Indian enticed me to eat and mask that taste in my mouth.  Hot foods rather than cold worked better for me too -- savouring them first before swallowing (I hope reading this doesn't make you sick!).  Maybe your onc can give you an appetite stimulant?  Your weight loss is quite dramatic -- I hope my suggestion works.  Hugs, Elizabeth xoxoxooo

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2010 05:18PM konakat wrote: Hi Brady -- I think it's highly unlikely that there would be two false negatives.  I would count on good news and another negative.  I understand it being worrisome -- we all worry even if our mind tells us everything's OK, we still worry.  I have a friend who has to go for follow-ups about every 4 months and it is very hard -- it's like there's no break in the stress.  In any case, I am counting on good news for you, and that they say "see you next year."  Good luck! Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2010 02:43PM konakat wrote: The problem is that the media want to present, and viewer see, a story with a happy ending.  Not the doom and gloom of mets.  But it's worth a try -- I hate that pink bandaid!  Rip!!!
Posts.Title: Pulling the Pink Band Aid Off Breast Cancer Terry3N Lowrider54

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2011 04:31PM - edited Mar 26, 2011 04:32PM by konakat Windy -- you have every right to feel down.  No one owns the corner on having a crappy time.  I know what you mean though about in comparison...  When I read about Olga, for example, I feel guilty for feeling sorry for myself.  I'm at the tail end of my '40s, I don't have little kids, I've got it so much easier in many ways.  But a friend explained to me that I shouldn't compare my situation to another's.  If I feel like my life is at it's worst, well, it is the worst for my reality.  I have every reason to feel like crap.  I hope this makes sense, she explained it so much better. And you just may feel normal for a long time, just a slightly different normal.  I often tell my doc how weird it is that I feel physically OK-ish when I have all this BC inside me.  It's very strange. I know that you're a very sweet, kind person -- your thread about etiquette and worries about your friend shows me this.  I wish you didn't have this stupid disease.  But we're all here together and look out for each other.  I'm blathering on (yet again) but I just want you to know that all your feelings are valid and we're here for you, always.
Posts.Title: PMS/ Feeling Down HELP! windy2011 sincitydealer

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2011 05:20PM konakat wrote: You will find a way Windy.  Finding something positive is hard.  My most positive thing is that I can say "No!" more easily and don't stand for BS as much.  I've re-evaluated what's important to me and what's trivial.  Kinda of like a housekeeping/sweeping of my priorities.  I try to plan a trip for when I feel better.  Something to look forward to, even if I don't do it.  Planning and dreaming is fun.  Tamox and PMS can really send you on an emotional down.  Certainly doesn't help dealing with the Stage IV crap.  If you keep feeling like crap perhaps consider an anti-depressent to take the edge off?  I've been on Effexor since before BC days.  I'm sure I'd be a monster without it. Hope this helps.  And, this place is great for the downers and venting.  It's what we specialize in!!  In time you'll find your way.  I'm sure you will.  Give it time.  Lots of hugs, Elizabeth
Posts.Title: PMS/ Feeling Down HELP! windy2011 sincitydealer

Posts.Content: May 24, 2011 06:24PM konakat wrote: The pain person upped my Fentalyn today and I see him on Monday to assess how I'm doing.  So at lease one thing is being dealt with quickly.   Drugs.....buzzzzzzzzzzzzzz
Posts.Title: Welcome to my Bizzaro World konakat CapeBretongirl

Posts.Content: konakat wrote: Very interesting day.  Even with the double transfusion on Sunday my lab results were even lower that the previous week's!!!  WTF!?!!  The nurse called Dr. McDreamy and he allowed the Navelbine but no carbo and no zometa (cracked tooth over the weekend).  Fair enough.  We'll try again next week. All this missing chemo is not helping my liver.  Some of the liver enzymes are 4-5x the levels from Feb.  Some as high as last summer/fall when I was really sick. I got the OK to double my pain meds.  I hope the Fentalyn wasn't the one causing the nausea and barfapalooza this weekend (I barfed all over myself on the Saturday). Now for the most bizzare.  The brain scan results.  The WBR didn't work on any of my brain lesions!!  I quote:  "...overall there is no significant progression and the lesions remain stable".  Normally this would be good news but it's not this time.  What do they mean no significant progression?  There wasn't supposed to be anything left, let alone no significant progression. This was my one and only best chance to get rid of them!  I was suspecting this a bit -- been having more weird SEs and just didn't mention them before.  Weakness in legs, clumpy walking, poor balance, dots swirling in from of my eyes, taking forever typing my post (this one 1.5 hours), weakness everywhere (lately my empty coffee pot feels like it weighs 20 pounds and I'm carrying bricks in my purse (I checked, no I'm not).... But I didn't expect the WBR to have no result with the leptomenigeal mets. I wonder what Mcdreamymuffin will say when I see him in 2 weeks.  So, there you have it, the long WBR blather.  I'm bitchy and grumpy.  Shocked, annoyed.  Pissed off. Thanks for caring and wondering what's been up. Elizabeth Go Canucks! Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Posts.Title: Welcome to my Bizzaro World konakat CapeBretongirl

Posts.Content: konakat wrote: Very interesting day.  Even with the double transfusion on Sunday my lab results were even lower that the previous week's!!!  WTF!?!!  The nurse called Dr. McDreamy and he allowed the Navelbine but no carbo and no zometa (cracked tooth over the weekend).  Fair enough.  We'll try again next week. All this missing chemo is not helping my liver.  Some of the liver enzymes are 4-5x the levels from Feb.  Some as high as last summer/fall when I was really sick. I got the OK to double my pain meds.  I hope the Fentalyn wasn't the one causing the nausea and barfapalooza this weekend (I barfed all over myself on the Saturday). Now for the most bizzare.  The brain scan results.  The WBR didn't work on any of my brain lesions!!  I quote:  "...overall there is no significant progression and the lesions remain stable".  Normally this would be good news but it's not this time.  What do they mean no significant progression?  There wasn't supposed to be anything left, let alone no significant progression. This was my one and only best chance to get rid of them!  I was suspecting this a bit -- been having more weird SEs and just didn't mention them before.  Weakness in legs, clumpy walking, poor balance, dots swirling in from of my eyes, taking forever typing my post (this one 1.5 hours), weakness everywhere (lately my empty coffee pot feels like it weighs 20 pounds and I'm carrying bricks in my purse (I checked, no I'm not).... But I didn't expect the WBR to have no result with the leptomenigeal mets. I wonder what Mcdreamymuffin will say when I see him in 2 weeks.  So, there you have it, the long WBR blather.  I'm bitchy and grumpy.  Shocked, annoyed.  Pissed off. Thanks for caring and wondering what's been up. Elizabeth Go Canucks! Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2011 10:13AM konakat wrote: Is your mom's arm swollen?  They way I check is I make fists and see if my knuckles are sticking out the same on both hands.  If it is lymphodema she needs to get her arm wrapped and/or a sleeve.  I don't know about the fever, if it's related. Since your mom just surgery a month ago she should call her surgeon's office see what he/she says about the fever.  And if it is lymphodema, to get a referral to a lymphodema specialist.  Hope this helps. Elizabeth

Posts.Content: May 10, 2011 03:29PM konakat wrote: I've only had Taxol and with a day or so of my infusion I got lots of aches and bone pain.  Neuropathy in my feet came on very slowly over the months.  When I was getting dose dense Taxol all my hair came out on Day 14.  When I had a lower dose Taxol with carbo my hair started thinning by the 3 cycle.  I didn't lose it all but it was thin.

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2010 10:37PM konakat wrote: My dearest Linda, I think of you often and was hoping for some news -- this is not what I was hoping for!  I can't imagine how horrible and scary it must be having such problems breathing.  So weird, just the past couple of days I've been thinking about radiation seeds -- having them plunked here and there in my liver.  It would be excellent to get it done for your lung -- good, focused radiation that works fast. Geez Linda -- this snuck up so fast, really pisses me off how sneaky BC can be.  You're always in my thoughts -- I hope you get good news tomorrow.  Love, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: May 25, 2011 04:37PM - edited May 25, 2011 04:54PM by konakat Thanks everyone.  I do have a little good news -- I see the dentist Fri 9AM.  Yikes.  I was reading up until 7AM today and booked at 8AM.  I have to remember not to read all night again!  The Fentalyn is working much better at the new dose but still needs considerable tweeking.  But I can walk! A GF has suggested a bunch of us get together in the Caribbean to hang out like old times.  Might be a fun, just in time for hurricane season! The worst is still Mom.  Hearing the shake in her voice when I told her.  I look into the homecare stuff - I have their info around somewhere.  Maybe ParaTranspo if I'm eligible.  I'm paying $40 each way for a taxi to and from the hospital.  I know there are volunteer drivers but I don't want to have to be friendly and also count on them being on time.

Posts.Content: konakat wrote: Very interesting day.  Even with the double transfusion on Sunday my lab results were even lower that the previous week's!!!  WTF!?!!  The nurse called Dr. McDreamy and he allowed the Navelbine but no carbo and no zometa (cracked tooth over the weekend).  Fair enough.  We'll try again next week. All this missing chemo is not helping my liver.  Some of the liver enzymes are 4-5x the levels from Feb.  Some as high as last summer/fall when I was really sick. I got the OK to double my pain meds.  I hope the Fentalyn wasn't the one causing the nausea and barfapalooza this weekend (I barfed all over myself on the Saturday). Now for the most bizzare.  The brain scan results.  The WBR didn't work on any of my brain lesions!!  I quote:  "...overall there is no significant progression and the lesions remain stable".  Normally this would be good news but it's not this time.  What do they mean no significant progression?  There wasn't supposed to be anything left, let alone no significant progression. This was my one and only best chance to get rid of them!  I was suspecting this a bit -- been having more weird SEs and just didn't mention them before.  Weakness in legs, clumpy walking, poor balance, dots swirling in from of my eyes, taking forever typing my post (this one 1.5 hours), weakness everywhere (lately my empty coffee pot feels like it weighs 20 pounds and I'm carrying bricks in my purse (I checked, no I'm not).... But I didn't expect the WBR to have no result with the leptomenigeal mets. I wonder what Mcdreamymuffin will say when I see him in 2 weeks.  So, there you have it, the long WBR blather.  I'm bitchy and grumpy.  Shocked, annoyed.  Pissed off. Thanks for caring and wondering what's been up. Elizabeth Go Canucks! Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Posts.Content: May 24, 2011 10:09PM - edited May 24, 2011 10:11PM by konakat I just broke off a big chunk of mine and my Zometa was cancelled until I see my new dentist. Possibly being overly cautious since my labs are so crappy but I'd rather not take the risk even though osteonecrosis of the jaw is very rare, or a bad infection I can't overcome.   I've been referred to the dentists at the hospital that are specially trained for treating chemo and poor immune systems patients.  Apparently extractions are more risky that crowns, but I'd check it out first with your dentist so it might be OK.

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2010 02:01AM konakat wrote: My swelling starts in my hand.  If you get a compression garment, make sure it's a gauntlet and not just a sleeve.  I started with a sleeve only and it seemed to trap the lymph in my hand and made it worse!  Anyone at risk should start wrapping as a preventative.  I think that's what has helped me a lot, starting early before it got too bad.

Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: konakat wrote: I'll start with the small bad news and work my way up to the really bad news.  I got my pre-trial scans back today -- now I have 8 lesions in my liver, one more lesion in my hip area, but my sternum and spine are stable (big f-ing whup).  Brain scan wasn't back yet this afternoon though... (can you see where this is going...) The lesions have mostly doubled in size since my Dec 15 scans.   Yikes.  OK, I say, let's blast them with the clinical trial drugs. Just got off the phone with Dr. McDreamy (my onc).  I'm out of the trial.  A tiny lesion was found in my brain.  F*ck (repeat several times with increasing intensity).  So, I get the cyber knife on March 10.  I stay on Aredia.  No chemo -- we're going to give Femara a try for a few weeks and see if I respond in my liver and bones.  If not, we'll give tykerb and I think xeloda a try.  I was zoning out in the conversation by then.  I'm finally freaking out.  I didn't cry when I got my progression news in January, which was weird.  I did this time, after I hung up the phone with Dreamykins.  Bawled to my b/f.  I'm still heading to Boston for the weekend, that will cheer me up.  F*ck.  I guess I will have to tell Mom about the progression sometime next week...joy oh joy...that's going to be the worst. So, I'm going to stuff my face, have a glass of wine, do a bit of cyberknife research here, then crawl into bed with Chloe (cat) so I'll be rested for tomorrow's trip.  I'll be on DeNile for a while too...it's nice there. Elizabeth Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Elizabeth's Mets: Liver, bones, brain (yuck), and lungs (more yuck). Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2010 03:55PM konakat wrote: I'll print out some stuff for my Mom to read -- good idea.  She'll think I'll end up brain dead with the radiation so I have to set her straight from the start.  I find the expressions on friends' faces when I tell them kinda funny. The horror!  I think saying one has a brain tumor has a certain caché, a mystery...  Of course, I can't stop talking like Arnie now, my tumah...  While I'm in deNile I might as well have fun with it. I used to think thank goodness it's not in my brain but the more I read it is more likely that my liver mets will be the end of me not my brain mets. As long as I don't lose my cognition it will be OK.  But then, that's would open a whole new barrel of laughs if I did...slap stick comedy here I come!

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2010 11:00AM konakat wrote: Well, well.  Going for the 10PM MRI wasn't bad.  I had a real cutie-patoutie!  He was pleasantly flirtatious but when the scan was over he seemed sad.  He must have noticed the tumah and didn't know I already knew about it.  Or he saw a bunch more with the MRI.  I gobbled up him telling me I'm an amazing woman. During the scan I thought I was having a reaction, my throat was tightening.  Freaked me out but I didn't stop the scan.  Ended up I was strangling myself with the johnny -- I shouldn't have tied it at the neckline.  So, now I have to remember to pee, blow nose, don't tie johnny.  I'm looking forward to getting the mask on Monday afternoon!  And seeing McDreamykins!
Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2010 02:24PM konakat wrote: Hellooooo!!  Well, getting the mask thingy wasn't so bad -- I just pretended it was a weird facial. It actually felt nice and warm.  No problem breathing.  But I can see where barfing would be a problem once your strapped in -- but I was relaxed the whole time, almost napping. When they put the big frame on all I could think was this is what an astronaut or deep sea diver feels like with a big helmet.  It cracked me right up. I saw McDreamy too and the plot thickens...  I had my finely sliced and diced MRI Friday night and he's waiting to hear back from the radiologist.  My tumah is near a blood vessel and he wants it confirmed that it is indeed mets, not just a wiggly blood vessel.  So hopefully I'll hear this evening or tomorrow sometime.  I still think it's a tumah... In any case I'm good to go for next Wed if it is. If it's not a tumah, I can hop right onto the trial I was supposed to go on.  If it is we just have to treat the tumor and then in 2 months try again for the trial.  So I'm optimistic either way.  But then, what's with the big honkin' blood vessel in my head -- that I'm trying not to think about (i.e., kaboom and splat!)!!  I get to see McDreamy again next week so hey, I'm having fun.  Thanks for all the well wishes -- your kindnesses just bowl me over. Elizabeth xoxoxo
Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2010 02:43PM konakat wrote: Hahahahahaaaa -- I think I'll go pour a glass right now!!  I think the magic pebble you gave me is giving me good luck Sharon!!
Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: konakat wrote: I'll start with the small bad news and work my way up to the really bad news.  I got my pre-trial scans back today -- now I have 8 lesions in my liver, one more lesion in my hip area, but my sternum and spine are stable (big f-ing whup).  Brain scan wasn't back yet this afternoon though... (can you see where this is going...) The lesions have mostly doubled in size since my Dec 15 scans.   Yikes.  OK, I say, let's blast them with the clinical trial drugs. Just got off the phone with Dr. McDreamy (my onc).  I'm out of the trial.  A tiny lesion was found in my brain.  F*ck (repeat several times with increasing intensity).  So, I get the cyber knife on March 10.  I stay on Aredia.  No chemo -- we're going to give Femara a try for a few weeks and see if I respond in my liver and bones.  If not, we'll give tykerb and I think xeloda a try.  I was zoning out in the conversation by then.  I'm finally freaking out.  I didn't cry when I got my progression news in January, which was weird.  I did this time, after I hung up the phone with Dreamykins.  Bawled to my b/f.  I'm still heading to Boston for the weekend, that will cheer me up.  F*ck.  I guess I will have to tell Mom about the progression sometime next week...joy oh joy...that's going to be the worst. So, I'm going to stuff my face, have a glass of wine, do a bit of cyberknife research here, then crawl into bed with Chloe (cat) so I'll be rested for tomorrow's trip.  I'll be on DeNile for a while too...it's nice there. Elizabeth Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Elizabeth's Mets: Liver, bones, brain (yuck), and lungs (more yuck). Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2010 09:29AM konakat wrote: It feels exactly like a hard ball, sort of protruding out.  Yuck.  I do what my onc does when he wants to check my liver -- take a deep breath, hold, and then poke around with a flat hand (i.e., not finger tips).  My happy place is a secluded tropical beach and I'm alone, lying on the beach, sun beating down on me, surf ticking my toes. Ahh, the palace -- being fed chocolate, cooed to (it's alright lizzie, here's some more chocolate, kiss, kiss...) by the palace favourites...

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2010 11:35AM konakat wrote: Oh Lisa -- you crack me up!  you're so right (like, duh) -- I guess I should take it easy for a week or so since they were mucking around with my brain!  I did feel a bit dizzier than usual this morning...I reported it to the nurse when I went for my Aredia.  With no guts and goo it's hard to think of it as surgery, but it is.  Another duh. I was just speaking to my b/f, I didn't notice all the calls I missed from him while I snoozed away yesterday.  I guess he was worried.  Teehee!!  If I go down the weekend of the 20th I'll be rested up.  There are lots of stopping places on the way in case I suddenly feel like crap.  I can just imagine it, Oh I feel faint, and there's a lovely B&B with a spa right at the next exit...how conveeeenient...
Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2010 03:48PM konakat wrote: My b/f's having financial issues, living in his sister's basement -- I do draw the line at a guy living with his Mom!  Heehee.  Poor pup.  I've made the trip 4 times since Dec; many, many times before I moved to Boston.  I wouldn't do it if he wasn't worth it.  He can be a sweetie. Linda -- you gotta be the smartest doofus I know!  Interesting you mentioned lemon -- I pick up a mini lemon pie today -- gotta keep up on my fruit consumption -- haha! It's funny this whole brain thing.  I have a sister I can't stand and hadn't talked to in years -- now she wants to call me (this is the evil sister, as opposed to my nice sister).  I picked up by mistake once -- gotta pay more attention to my call display.  I do enjoy hearing about her fretting.  Though I do know that she and my equally evil brother are tallying up their inheritance without me being around to get my share.  People I haven't spoken to for ages that have heard through the grapevine are contacting me.  What am I, a freak show?  This is all so strange, yet entertaining.
Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2010 03:01PM konakat wrote: Teehee -- most everyone caved!  I am very stubborn sometimes!  If I feel like crap I won't go.  I did postpone this past weekend -- which was good since the weather sucked in Boston, not that I would be out in it much, but still... I'm just lolling about all week, should be good for the drive on Saturday.  I'm going nuts waiting for my next appt with McDreamypants (Mar 30) -- I feel like I'm in limbo. If I could I'd get scanned all the time -- I hate not knowing what's going on.  Maybe he'll order some scans when I see him.  Pant, pant...
Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2010 05:04PM - edited Mar 18, 2010 05:05PM by konakat I'm still dizzy.  The oncs said I probably wasn't having any SEs from the tumah since it was so small.  I thought I was less dizzy after the big zap but maybe not.  All I can think is that it's the Aredia.  It has dizziness as an SE. Now I'm reading up on necrosis -- the zap gives a 10% chance of this.  The bugger is that it can be a delayed SE -- maybe up to a year away!  Talk about dramatic tension for a year.  My tumah was right beside a blood vessel too.  I sure hope cute physicist got his numbers right.  3katz -- did you know sugar, which comes from sugarcane, a plant that kinda looks like celery, can be substituted for celery?  Yah...that comes from my rules of oink-out rationalization. I'm morose today.  Yesterday I went for lunch with a friend (fun!) but it was near the high tech place I used to work at.  Made me wistful.  The good ol' days... Whaaaaaaa!
Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2010 03:54PM konakat wrote:   Thanks for thinking of me!  I'll have a list of questions for him.  It just occurred to me yesterday about waiting for the trial -- Since I have/had brain bugs does TDM1 get through the blood brain barrier?  It's a new drug so they probably don't know that yet.  TDM's Herceptin in disguise, hitching ride on another chemo so it's probably pretty big --  getting through the BBB would be like me squeezing into a size 4 pair of jeans!  It ain't gonna happen!  Perhaps we should forget about the trial and start me on Xeloda right away.  Thoughts anyone? And why am I always dizzy -- the Aredia?  And what's with my neck -- it's been sore for months -- I think it's the osteopenia but what if it's more?  I wanna be scanned again to see if the Femara is holding off the ickies.  And I sleep all the time -- what's with that?  Can't wait to see McSleepypants tomorrow.

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2009 02:35PM konakat wrote: You are not shallow or vain!  I laughed at the "faux cleaning".  Maybe have the house presentable but the cleaning people scrub a stove top, vacuum, dust for the cameras.  Nothing gross like a bathroom -- too personal a space! Re. wig or scarf, or hat:  If you only wear the wig for special occasions it sounds like you're comfortable with friends and neighbours seeing you sans wig.  If that's the case, wear your baseball cap. Who cares about people you don't know? Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2010 01:22PM - edited Apr 27, 2010 01:28PM by konakat Mary -- the week of May 11th is good, except for May 11th when I see my oncologist.  Other than that I'm free.  Probably the best week in May since I hope to being tests/scans for a clinical trial towards the end of the month. Renee -- Hope the trial is going well and your side doesn't hurt anymore.  I was scared the first time I gave Chloe fluids so I just grabbed her scruff and jabbed.  I either do it or I have a sick cat on my hands.  Edit:  Just saw your new thread -- I'll catch up there. Barbe -- Chloe doesn't act old -- still playful and loves rolling around and getting her tummy tickled.  She does have a bit of arthritis in her hind legs though.  She looks pretty good for an old lady -- 89 in human years.  I'm usually hunched over her on the floor kissing her ears and head so she can't get away.  It wasn't easy getting the pics!

Posts.Content: May 4, 2010 01:57PM - edited May 4, 2010 02:00PM by konakat Thanks everyone!  I just got up an hour ago after sleeping for 16 hours.  The weekend was wonderful even though I got pissy at one point and told my bf to f-off.  But we made up.  One of the best parts was stuffing ourselves with donuts for dinner and watching TV.  Just relaxing and hanging out. The brain scan won't entail the horrid mask -- just a generic thingy to hold my head stable.  No biggie.  Except for having to be there at 9AM!!!  That will be torture. I want to pick up the scan results before I see Dr. McDuffus so I won't be side-tracked by the results (and his velvety voice).  I want to be sure to tell him that I was not amused by being blind-sided by the 6 week wait to see him, only a brain scan, his witchy nurse (no offense to witches) blah, blah.  I cannot wait until next Tuesday!!!! Shiny -- it's all one doc -- his name changes depending on how I feel about him at the time.  Maybe I could draw cartoons based on what I think of him to match the labels.

So, I'm going to stuff my face, have a glass of wine, do a bit of cyberknife research here, then crawl into bed with Chloe (cat) so I'll be rested for tomorrow's trip.  I'll be on DeNile for a while too...it's nice there. Elizabeth Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Elizabeth's Mets: Liver, bones, brain (yuck), and lungs (more yuck). Posts.Title: results of MRI shows new lesion :( pegcz konakat

Posts.Content: May 13, 2009 04:42PM konakat wrote: Even if you have the surgery there is no 100% guarantee that all the cancer is gone.  If it has gone to your nodes there is the worry that it could go further, to other organs (that's what mets is).  You need to treat your entire system -- chemo does this.  I was horrified at the thought of chemo too.  I just didn't want to face it but I did, the alternative was much scarier. The side effects can be handled with medications.  it's not a cake-walk, but it's worth it.  Some people gain a bit of weight, others not.  But that is such a minor thing compared to risking the cancer returning or spreading.

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2010 03:35PM konakat wrote: Good grief.  You've been getting a lot of crap thrown your way lately.  If you tested negative for all types of hepatitis I hope the biopsy doesn't show some dormant form.  And I hope you get the biopsy ASAP to get this behind you.  Not that it has any validity, I have this feeling that you don't have hepatitis.  I've been googling too.  Seems like there are patients that continue with chemo while having active hepatitis.  No matter the result, it sounds like time to tweak your treatment to get your liver numbers under control.  If you do have hepatitis, your onc and liver doc can work together to give you the best treatment. Please don't say you're a goner!  I really like you and don't want to lose you!!!  Please keep us updated on things...  Lots of hugs, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2010 09:04PM konakat wrote: Finally home after celebrating with pizza and wine.  The zapping was very easy, except for the first 5 minutes when I wanted to scream, get out of the damn thing and get some sedatives.  I came sooooo close to freaking out but then I just relaxed, breathed slowly and it was fine.  It was cool that they wouldn't start zapping before they got the final sign-off from the physicist.  They did have to do one readjustment that involved me wiggling down the table thing.  OK, he was about my height (5'4" - kinda short), gorgeous wavy, long, dark hair, and a really nice smile.  I wish everyone would have stopped calling me Mrs Blair!  And hey, at least I know he's interested in my brain!  I thanked him profusely for doing a good job on the math.  If I need another zapping I'll know to wear a skirt and no undies to expedite the flirtation!  Hahahahaaaa! So, no twitching, no swelling, no nausea.  Hmmmph.  Nothing.  It's like nothing was done.  No bravery involved at all.  It all comes down to choosing between getting zapped or dropping dead in the near future.  A no brainer!  Haha -- couldn't resist! I didn't get to keep the mask.  :-(  Apparently some are of the type people can take home but they wanted to keep mine, just in case...  Sigh.... Well, SEs can show up for a week, so I still could go wonky.  :-)

So you don't think I'm a homewrecker or anything, Wally is Sharon's gorgeous chocolate lab -- I got to smother him with kisses and hugs the other day.  Lots of them Coonie!  And I got lots of licks and lovin' in return.  We're a real item now!  Heehee.  No picture for my fridge though.  Hmmmm.  I'm gonna relax for the next few days, head off to see my other b/f in Boston next week.  I'm too flippin' tired.  19 more days until I see McDreamy...

So, I'm going to stuff my face, have a glass of wine, do a bit of cyberknife research here, then crawl into bed with Chloe (cat) so I'll be rested for tomorrow's trip.  I'll be on DeNile for a while too...it's nice there. Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2010 10:23PM konakat wrote: You could use this event in your life as a moment to start reevaluating other parts of your life.  As you are healing your body you can come up with a plan to heal your life, make it better - like starting with a clean slate or turning the page to a new chapter. I too have had many why bother feelings, just give up chemo since my life is not what I ever hoped it would be - no kids, no significant other, lost my sense of purpose. I only have my dear cat to keep me going some days.  What helps is my curiosity about what could be different, what's around the corner for me -- I don't want to miss out on anything that could be good.  Perhaps think of one thing that you'd like to change, something that is attainable, and focus on that.  It can be a quick change or something that will take a lot of time.  Also embrace what you want to stay the same.  Now is the time to be selfish -- it's all about you.  Take care of you.  Weed out what you don't need/want and hang on to what you do.  This is what I try to do, sometime with success, sometimes not, but it's OK no matter what.  Hugs, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2009 05:11PM konakat wrote: Perhaps your dr was describing a cyst or an abscess?  I know it will be nerve-wracking waiting until Tuesday, but once you have the mammo, make sure they fully describe the results to you and what they will do.  I kept asking questions and took notes the first time I had a funky mammo and they suspected cancer. I did a quick search here and here's part of a post from 2007 - I don't know if it is similar to what you have, but it has some good info.  And good luck on Tuesday, let us know how it went. "Inflammed ducts", breast ducts enlarged and filled with inflammatory cells (the kinds associated with infections) do indeed occur even unassociated to pregnancies. Many may be without symptoms, and if symptoms occur, they may be some localized breast pain, nipple discharge, and even an abscess or pus pocket which might drain to the skin. The inflammatory cells can obstruct secretions within the duct and the duct enlarges, and is more susceptible to infection. This can happen even unrelated to pregnancy and breast feeding, where breast infections are more commonly seen. Perhaps your doctor will recommend a sonogram of the biopsied area to visualize the duct involved, and recommend the duct be excised. This may minimize any likelihood of further inflammation, infection, abscess and/or tracks from the duct to the skin (called fistulas). Though it sounds somewhat scary, breast surgeons deal with breast ducts all the time in breast practices.

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2010 10:17AM konakat wrote: Thanks for the tips Darlene!  And 11 zaps and 3 hours - now that's what I call endurance!  What if your nose gets stuffed up and you can't open your mouth to breath?  Yikes!  Mental note: Pee and blow nose before zapping.  I found out that my hospital isn't getting the cyberknife until May.  I'll get zapped with an old crappy machine instead.  But at least my rad guy will have lots of experience with it.  He assured me it works the same way, it's just a different machine.  Yikes!  Now I'm thinking back to the Far Side cartoon I posted!  Hahahhaaa!! Isn't that sweet? Right now I'm only on Aredia and Femara.  Some days I think the Femara is working -- fewer liver twinges.  But then my supposedly stable spine mets are making my back really sore.  From one of the websites Chainsawz sent me there was an interesting article that says Femara can get through the BBB.  Since most women have tried AIs and had them fail by the time they got brain mets they didn't have a lot of data to show that it sometimes works.  Also interesting is that more ER- women get brain mets than ER+.  So in a way it's good that I have never been stable enough to try AIs and still have them as a option.  Also, if you have lots or big brain lesions the BBB breaks down and lets more types of chemo through -- kinda a catch-22 with that one. Posts.Content: May 11, 2010 11:46AM - edited May 11, 2010 11:48AM by konakat I LOVE Dr. McDreamy.  He ackowledged my stress and cooed and coddled me -- just what I needed.  And up-ed my Effexor. My brain scan came back clean!  Yippee!  Of course I still have a dirty mind. The lumpy-bump is probably a cyst but he's ordering a mammo anyway. In the next 2-3 weeks I will get a bone scan (re. aches), chest and abdomen CT (re. liver still swollen, as usual), brain MRI, echo, etc in prep for the clinical trial and to get a good idea what's up.  We'll discuss options in 3 weeks.  He did say if Femara is working I should stay with it and not X-off my options by going on the trial too soon.  I told him that Femara seemed to work at first (less pain) but the pains are coming back so even if the scans are better than they were in January I could still be getting worse again.  I guess we'll see in a couple of weeks. He also mentioned that for HER2+ there's another drug in Phase 1 trials (not TDM1 but something new) and there's lots coming down the pipeline.  This is good! I feel a lot better!!!!  And, I can now get my hair done without worrying about wasting the money.  And relax a bit.  I can't wait until the scans -- I love getting scans.  But for the next couple of weeks I'll probably be boring re. posts.  :-) Thanks for all the well wishes!!

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2010 10:34AM konakat wrote: Things are moving very fast -- I see the radiation oncologist tomorrow morning!  This is great, yet worrisome, yet great!  I've always had this rule of thumb -- if an appt is rescheduled to later, you're doing fine.  If it's fast, oh-oh.  I know -- I should be please that it's happening so fast but it's freakin' me out!
Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: Feb 22, 2010 07:17AM konakat wrote: I'm kinda torn on the timing of telling Mom the latest.  I am pretty sure I'll mention it this week when I drop by for a visit.  But then, she'll have a hissy worry fit if I drive down to Boston before zap day.  Then, my sister says wait and if all goes well with the zapping don't mention anything.  But I'm tired of secrets.  Also, if I take a really bad turn for the worst Mom will be better prepared.  Arrrrgh!!!!!   I hate having to worry about others' reactions!  It's too stressful.  Just blathering...
Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2010 07:54PM konakat wrote: Hehehe Ruth -- I like cats so maybe a cat 'o' nine tails?  We should work that into our 5 word stories!!  Good thing I don't like fava beans and liver.  Cake, ice cream, and a chianti --now that sounds good!
Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2010 08:32PM konakat wrote: Oh, I forgot to post the funniest thing -- when I'm getting my pre-zap brain MRI.  The stupid MRI dept is always late in scheduling.  My rad onc's nurse called to make sure I had everything set up and I mentioned that the MRI wasn't scheduled. She chased them down for me. The duffuses (duffi, what the plural of duffus?) got the faxed req over a week ago and were so surprised that the MRI had to be done before March 1.  Sooooo, I get my MRI this Friday at 10PM!!!  I think that is just so weird.  At least I have a hot date for Friday!!  I think it will be a long MRI -- they slice and dice the pics at 1mm (instead of 5mm) sections.  Maybe they'll find some more tumor critters.  I see McDreamy on Monday <pant, pant> and will ask.
Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2010 02:58PM - edited Mar 1, 2010 02:59PM by konakat Just got off the phone with McDreamy.  Apparently there was a big conference call and they're 99.9% sure (the radiologists 100% sure, McDreamy took some convincing) it is mets and not something else so I get zapped March 10.  And I won't see McDreamybabycakes until after that -- about 2-3 weeks.  Waaaaah!  My mask is weird -- they hooked this pliable plastic thingy in my mouth to bite on so when everything cooled the mask is held in place with the help of this hardened thing against my upper front teeth.  At least I can swallow, breath easily, and make gurgly noises if required... So tumah is there and only one of them -- they didn't find any more with the MRI. And in about 3 months time I can be on the trial again...assuming Femara keeps me from dropping dead in the meantime!  Ho-hum... No cake, but I see pizza in the near future...
Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2010 07:33PM konakat wrote: Back from the bawdy side...I have a question: While we deal with the brain mets and wait for the opportunity to try for the trial again I'm only on Femara.  Between Dec and Feb my liver mets doubled in size and number (the largest is 4cm!).  I worry that we should be throwing the bigger guns at the BC -- not wait for the trial and just go for Xeloda/Tykerb right away.  I worry that Femara is wasting time, we should hit the BC hard now.  Or maybe not...  Thoughts anyone?  Thanks!!
Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2009 11:14AM konakat wrote: From my own thoughts and experience, I find that my priorities have changed, that things that used to be important I just don't care about.  I had one friend who was upset over her hair thinning over a thyroid problem and she then apologized, saying it's a little thing compared to my problems.  But I didn't mind, to her it was important so she has a right to feel bad. When it comes to our partners and loved ones I think we should have higher standards.  I'm sure some people who know my personal situation are guffawing, hearing this coming from me!  I understand DreamWeaver's situation.  We put up with crap when we know we deserve so much better.  God forbid we have a day of venting, saying how awful this sux, and then get accused of being selfish and nagging.  I don't know why we put up with this.  We love the man?  We don't want to be alone at the end?  I crave the love I see others have but I don't think I'll ever have it, especially being stage IV. Dreamweaver, it worries me that you are becoming fearful.  I know it is so very easy to say, but you should do some soul searching, think about leaving this man.  Yes, coming from me it's kind hypocritical, but I know it's the right thing to do.  I hope we both have the strength to do what is ultimately the best for us, no matter how scary and painful it is in the short term. Love, Elizabeth
Posts.Title: should we be treated different because you are stage IV? Fitztwins Fitztwins

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2010 09:38AM konakat wrote:
Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2010 02:43PM konakat wrote: Gasp!  Oh YUM!!!!  Sharon -- you've got me pegged!  Reminds me of a funny story.  I was hiking in the Gaspe and managed to do the whole trail without incident.  Walking to the car I tripped and ripped open my knee on the pavement.  It was a really deep gash.  I was freaking out -- it was awful. To calm me down on the way to the hospital to get stitched up my b/f stopped to get me an ice cream.  Smart man.  I regressed to toddler mode -- snivelling and licking my ice cream cone. It made me feel much better. Another time I was really depressed and hadn't eaten for days.  A girlfriend shoved a chocolate chip cookie in my mouth -- the beginning of my recovery. I have lots of stories where desserts have calmed me down.  Tomorrow night -- ice cream and cake for dinner.  I'm freaking out a bit now -- not so much the tumah but all the BC.  I'm not ready for my swan song -- I still have a few things I want to do.
Posts.Title: Really crappy news :-(((( konakat pee

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2010 03:48PM konakat wrote: The zapping is set for March 10.  Can't wait!  I also saw where it is on the scan -- cerebellum, left side, about 1 inch deep.  I don't have any SEs now and the rad guy doesn't expect any after the zapping.  I get one of those cool face masks a la Anthony Hopkins/Silence of the Lambs made for me to keep me from moving during the zapping -- I hope they let me keep it!  He did recommend someone drive me on zap day though.  Otherwise it kinda sounds like a non-event.  Of course that will change as the day approaches. Since one's gait and balance are controlled by the cerebellum I should apply as a consultant for the Ministry of Silly Walks (Monty Python).  You know, I'm gonna have fun with this -- silly walks!  I'll try not to embarrass you, Mich and Sharon, when I see you next -- mouhouhahahahaaaa! I am so thankful I was considered for the trial and had all that testing -- otherwise it could have been way worse and not found until I did have a silly walk.  Just a teeny tumah, not a big fat one.  There's always hope...thanks for being there (again and again) for me ladies.  Hugs, Elizabeth

Here's my stupid news.  McSteamy would have liked to have known about my dizziness and neck pain ages ago.  Hopefully my next bunch of scans will show what's up -- so far it's a mystery.  I see McDreamykins in 3 weeks to get the scan results and find out if I can still do the trial or if my liver is too wonky and we need to start Xeloda and Tykerb right away.  The scans will also pick up Herbie the Hernia and see if it needs more treatment (it's not bugging me now). I asked about TDM getting through the BBB -- they don't know.  He also said we don't know how well Xeloda and Tykerb get through either -- WTF?  In my grumpiness I blurted out "So I'm f*cked no matter what?"  Not necessarily (yet, anyway) -- my liver is the biggest concern and going on the trial or starting on the meds immediately will be a good thing. Oh, okaaaaay.  I didn't ask about my labs -- I wonder if my liver is worse...I don't want to know.  It doesn't hurt as much but you never know...he looked concerned...could be my imagination...I hope my brain doesn't explode, my neck break, turn yellow (I do like the colour though).  I'm grumpy. So, three f*-ing weeks to find out what's next.

I just had a meltdown on the phone with my onc's nurse's voicemail <insert applause>.  I just got my appt sheet in the mail and it said May 11th is my next onc appt. <insert lots of swearing, stomping around>.  I left a message that I was expecting my appt no later than 3 weeks after seeing Mc-not-so-Dreamy, with scans ready and read.  AND, in fact I want it earlier since I haven't been on chemo since December, I have progression and I'm in the middle of a nervous breakdown.  When I get really pissed off my voice shakes so I sounded suitable melted.  My hands are shaking, they want to pummel something.  Not McDreamy...yet...
