Posts.Content: konakat wrote: I'll start with the small bad news and work my way up to the really bad news.  I got my pre-trial scans back today -- now I have 8 lesions in my liver, one more lesion in my hip area, but my sternum and spine are stable (big f-ing whup).  Brain scan wasn't back yet this afternoon though... (can you see where this is going...) The lesions have mostly doubled in size since my Dec 15 scans.   Yikes.  OK, I say, let's blast them with the clinical trial drugs. Just got off the phone with Dr. McDreamy (my onc).  I'm out of the trial.  A tiny lesion was found in my brain.  F*ck (repeat several times with increasing intensity).  So, I get the cyber knife on March 10.  I stay on Aredia.  No chemo -- we're going to give Femara a try for a few weeks and see if I respond in my liver and bones.  If not, we'll give tykerb and I think xeloda a try.  I was zoning out in the conversation by then.  I'm finally freaking out.  I didn't cry when I got my progression news in January, which was weird.  I did this time, after I hung up the phone with Dreamykins.  Bawled to my b/f.  I'm still heading to Boston for the weekend, that will cheer me up.  F*ck.  I guess I will have to tell Mom about the progression sometime next week...joy oh joy...that's going to be the worst. So, I'm going to stuff my face, have a glass of wine, do a bit of cyberknife research here, then crawl into bed with Chloe (cat) so I'll be rested for tomorrow's trip.  I'll be on DeNile for a while too...it's nice there. Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2010 06:18PM - edited Apr 21, 2010 06:19PM by konakat No, I haven't graduated to glasses on a chain.  I have one good prescription pair in the living room for when I'm on my laptop.  And cheapos in my bedroom (reading, duh) and in my purse.  I should get my eyes tested.  My b/f has a thing for women in glasses.  He got quite excited when he found out I used to be a librarian.  Yah, I know -- so much crap in our food.  I never forget years ago I went for dinner at a place that bought their meat from a local place -- no chemicals.  It tasted like meat from when I was a kid.  When you think what is sprayed on our crops and makes it up through the food chain makes me shudder.  My Dad was a farmer and all the oats he planted had some pesticide coated on them.  Ugh.  But the dairy cows (Holsteins) were healthy -- only ate grass in the fields (no pesticides) and hay from the fields.  He bred Holsteins too, no hormones, nice healthy moo-cows.  Who know what they do to the poor things now. Re. photo of Mcdreamy -- he's online all over the place -- speaks at a lot of events that have been recorded, on the news, etc.  He's dark, tall, fit, a sprinkling of grey in his hair, voice like melted dark chocolate.  And he's all mine -- mouhouhahahahahaaaaa!!

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2010 04:15PM - edited Apr 24, 2010 04:17PM by konakat Thanks - it was a bit of a pathetic post.  I'm feeling a bit better -- I drove out to Mom's to pick up some moula so I can take Chloe for her check-up at the vet (shhh, she doesn't know yet) and saw the leaves out, cows (I moo-ed at them) and some Canada geese (honk, honk).  And lots of cute groundhogs.  I love groundhogs.  I wonder if I can find a cheap place to live in the country... Funny story -- A few years ago I said hi to a groundhog along the highway (I always do that) and the next day he was still in the same place so I was sad that he was probably dead.  Later in the week I went by the same place and saw that it wasn't a groundhog but a rock.  Cheered me up, but felt silly thinking it was a groundhog. I think I will be in a better frame of mind once my treatment is set in May -- no longer in limbo land.  And maybe get a boost in my Effexor.  Edit to add:  Linda you didn't bum me out.  It's been on my mind a lot.

Posts.Content: May 4, 2010 02:10PM - edited May 4, 2010 02:10PM by konakat Oh, here's another highlight from the weekend -- something I never though I'd do.  I snuggled a pit bull!!!  We went to a friend's and her dog greeted us at the door.  I see a dog, oooh, cuddle time.  I asked her what kind of dog and she said pit bull.  I froze -- I'm terrified of pit bulls, or at least their jaws ( I know there are no bad dogs, just bad owners, still...).  Her tail stopped wagging.  I stood up, gave my friend a hug hello and the dog started bumping into my legs to separate us.  I asked if she could sense fear, everyone there said yes.  So she was put into her kennel.  I'm a wimp -- the dog gets along with her 2 cats so she must be well behaved.  And she was very pretty.  Still, never thought I'd have my arms around a pit bull and kissing the top of her head.  Edit:  I think I'll stick to cuddling Sharon's Wally.  :-)

Posts.Content: May 13, 2009 05:06PM konakat wrote: Yes, it is possible to work through chemo.  I got my chemo on Friday and took the Monday off to rest.  What's strange is that the side effects don't happen immediately -- I didn't feel queasy/fluish until Sunday.  If I had to work on Monday I could of, but I chose not to. Also, the first med I was given for nausea wasn't good enough.  I called my onc on the Monday and they had me come back in for some fluids and a new prescription.  So, be vocal and they will help you deal with side effects. I didn't address hairloss - yes, it sucks big ones, but it all comes down to weighing the alternative.  With extensions and wigs so much in style you'll find a good one if that's what you want to do.  Get a couple.  I got one in hot pink from wigs.com. And, when your hair grows back it, it is so soft and curly.  My hair never looked better -- that was one consolation prize for the chemo. There are these ice caps/hats that you can wear that are supposed to stop hairloss, but I have yet to see anyone that says they worked.  Apparently it just slows down the loss, but it eventually all comes out.  As you go on this journey, we will try to help by sharing our experiences, and listening to yours.

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2009 05:19PM - edited Aug 22, 2009 05:26PM by konakat Hi Cheryl -- My thoughts on this is, if the ER doc didn't consult with a kidney doc and/or onc I'd want more info.  The stent will provide immediate relief, but what is the long-term impact on your overall care?  I don't think an ER doc can answer that.  If it were me, I would ask my onc to consult with a kidney specialist, ASAP.  With the combined expertise of your onc and the kidney specialist, they will come up with the best solution.  Some questions I would ask -- does your onc expect dramatic, fast results (as some chemos do) so your relief will come quickly without a stent?  Is there a risk of infection with a stent?  Can better pain meds manage the pain until the chemo takes effect and reduces the pressure? I'm sorry I don't have any good advice on to stent or not to stent, just a few ideas that may help you decide. Take care, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2010 01:07AM konakat wrote: I really freaked about getting a port.  Having this foreign thing in my body.  Something left in my body to remind me of chemo.  I kept thinking about the Borg from Star Trek for some reason.  And getting an infection -- the port was the fast lane to my heart for germs.  What if my cat scratches it and I die of some cat poo disease?  I was much happier getting jabbed 3 or 4 times with an IV.  But I relented, although totally terrified.  But now, I have to say I love my port!  It is so easy.  Virtually painless to get hooked up for chemo.  Two free hands!  I can go to the bathroom, do up my pants easily and not set off the beeper on the IV machine!  I don't feel as tied down as I did with the IV in my arm. And you can have fun with it.  Mine sticks out so when a friend asked what it was I said my b/f planted a chip in me so he could keep track where I am, or it's a homing device.  Next time I'll say I got it when I was abducted by aliens and it can't be removed. I absolutely understand when you say it sucks.  Absolutely.  I hated the idea of it.  Now I love it.  I've only had it since the 2nd week of January and it's now a non-event.  I wish I got it ages ago -- would have saved my veins and not require lab techs to root around looking for a vein.

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2009 05:15PM - edited Nov 12, 2009 05:17PM by konakat I was an abberation -- after 2 treatments I was lobster red!!  Beet red!!!  Around my incisions and more delicate skin at my collarbone I got toasty brown too that eventually cracked and kinda chipped off.  Luckily no blisters.  I slathered on that cream they gave me immediately after being zapped and a couple of more times during the day.  The red went away quickly after the rads finished though.  Fatigue happened the last 2 weeks.  Otherwise, a walk in the park!  :-) Edit to add:  I also got these little dots, sort of looked like black heads (yuck, I know).  I think it was just dead skin trapped in pores.  Yuck again.  But it eventually disappeared.

Posts.Content: Nov 12, 2009 09:55PM - edited Nov 12, 2009 10:00PM by konakat The nurse gave me this little tub of Aquaphor.  Never heard of it before but I guess it worked.  It's all coming back to me -- I remember my onc saying that if you're on Herceptin when you get rads you can sometimes (rarely) get a beet red boob, but it's not dangerous. She consulted with the rad onc and the pharmacist and they said don't worry. So I didn't.  :-) The fatigue took a few months to go away I'm sorry to say.  I think it was a combo of all the chemo, rads, and emotional drain.  Hit me like a brick wall during rads towards the end, but it was nice to be at the end.  Some breeze through treatment, some don't, and everything in between is experienced.  But don't worry if you start to feel tired.  I managed to work through the whole thing so it's doable.  Just remember to get the energy to celebrate like h*ell when it's all over!!!! Oh yeah, Aquaphor is a bit greasy so don't wear your best bra/camisole/whatever.  Oh yeah (again) my boob swelled a bit too, not really noticable.

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2011 08:41PM konakat wrote: Vivo!!!!  Congratulations about your first grandchild!!  What a wonderful summer it will be! I stuggle with my bone mets pain.  I play around with various painkillers and just can't get the right combo working.  I use ibuprofen (inflammatory pain), codeine and sometimes morphine for general pain.  I had rads to a very fragile area of my spine and it got rid of the pain immediately and caused some new healthy bone growth.  For non-medicinal things that work wonders for me:  A nice and hot bubble bath.  Really -- as soon as I lower myself into the tub a lot of the pain goes away.  Same thing with cuddling a heating pad.  I think these work for the aching muscles that are trying to support bones, not directly on the bones.  But it sure feels good. I hope some of these work for you if you haven't tried some yet.  Pain is just so demoralizing -- hard to want to get out and participate in life. Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2009 12:19PM konakat wrote: Hi Krystyna -- I've been following your thread -- I have liver mets and bone mets.  The bone was only 1 lesion on my spine and the Zometa (first on Aredia, very similar) took care of it quickly.  I hope you get a similar response.  They do have it in Canada (forget the brand name) -- which makes me happy since I'm moving back to Ottawa in a month!!! I've had liver mets from the beginning -- 2.5 years and still doing quite well.  Been on chemo for about 11 months -- at first horrible taxol and carboplatin, now Gemzar. Other than being tired a bit I'm fine.  I don't much about liver resections, but if I could get one I'd jump for it.  The liver is one of those wonderful organs that you can remove quite a bit of it and do fine.  I have too many lesions to make it worth it.  If you get the opportunity for one that's great!!!! I originally freaked at the stats for liver mets but my onc says she doesn't see why I won't be around for 5 years, possible longer.  And, there are quite a few women here who have been living with liver and bone mets for quite a while -- gives me a lot of hope!!  It doesn't sound like long, 5 years, but when you think of everything that can get packed into that amount of time I'm OK with it.  I'm sorry your trip had to be cancelled.  But once you get the mets under control and your spine strengthened maybe in the spring?  I hope so!!  This has been such a terrible shock to you, I know.  Once you get your treatment plan set up and get on it you will feel more in control, feel that you're on the mend.  With love, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2010 03:20PM konakat wrote: I'm squished!  I'm squished!  So many hugs!  I'm overwhelmed with your kind thoughts.  I just got up from my nap and cat cuddle.  Funny thing is that I'm not crying yet.  Maybe I'm used to bad news or it hasn't sunk in yet.  I did eat a lot of chocolate though.  And yes Sharon - we have to get together for dessert and coffee soon!  I shocked her and Mich by not ordering dessert when we had lunch yesterday.  I was on my meeting-someone-new good behaviour.  Since I did OK I can embarrass myself next time.  My sweetie pie onc was so kind -- a big hug after delivering the news.  He's running the trial and I know I'm in good hands.  I told him I want to start now but there's all those tests to do, blah, blah, blah.  The clinical trial manager said if she didn't get a good response (i.e., the samples are on the way) from the Boston hospital she'd call me early next week so I can unleash my ass-kicking onc down there.  Oh well, onward and upward.  Mom has always used this British phrase "keep your pecker up" and I'd always reply "I don't have a pecker."  Now why that just came to my mind I don't know.  Thought I'd share.  :-)
Posts.Title: Progression in liver and bones :-( konakat dreamwriter

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2010 12:17PM konakat wrote: Thank-you sistahs!!!  I made the decision today to go on disability.  I just can't see myself working fulltime.  A lot of it is facilitating focus groups (trying to be dynamic and not really giving a f---, running to the bathroom with the poops, deadlines...).  It will be tough since I'll be living on crap money with a little help from Mom.  But I've been fortunate up until the past year.  I've since weaned myself off Holt Renfrew and Neiman Marcus.  I'm a KMart and flea market girl now.  Business suits are going on consignment.  But it is a relief -- I can relax, do some volunteer work for the Humane Society, focus on getting better. My sister had some words of wisdom.  I was thinking I totally f'ed up, getting myself into this state of dependence on others.  But she said Mother Nature let me down.  It's true.  Mother Nature has let us all down. We don't deserve this crap.  It just happened.
Posts.Title: Progression in liver and bones :-( konakat dreamwriter

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2010 08:33AM konakat wrote: Unfortunately Herceptin has been crossed off my list.  My mets came back the first time and then had this progression while on Herceptin.  The super Herceptin sounds very good, interesting on how it works.  Even if I don't get on the trial I'll go ahead with the Xeloda.  Re. getting my slides -- I will be in Boston the last week of Jan so if worse comes to worst I can pick up the d*mn slides!!  I would be nice to see my old onc and nurses -- they have a very large place in my heart, right by the dessert table. Pineapple cake is good!  It will cover my fruit consumption for the day!! I still can't figure out why I'm not freaking out.  When my mets came back at the end of 2008 I was a mess.  I had to stay in the onc's office for an extra 2 hours until my bp went down.  But then, I've had an additional year here, seen so many women kick their mets down and do well.  I think you ladies are such a calming bunch.  If we could bottle the vibes we'd put the anti-depression med industry out of business.

Posts.Title: Progression in liver and bones :-( konakat dreamwriter

Posts.Content: konakat wrote: Well, I wasn't expecting the news I got today.  I was scanned up the kazoo (figuratively, not literally, haha) in November and there was just my usual one stubborn liver lesion.  Same old, same old.  I was expecting the same thing today from the results of my December scans.  In one month the cancer roared back.  Two new lesions on my liver (plus my old one), old spine lesion back, and new ones on my sternum, and a suspicious blip on my hipbone.  And a suspicious blip on my lung.  Kinda explains why my back has started to hurt again.  And stupid me, I thought the pain in my right side was just poor posture from being a couch potato.  Interesting how the mind can blank out the obvious. I guess it's a moot point that I don't get Gemzar anymore...  The exciting thing is that I am being considered for a trial.  Comparison of Trastuzumab-MCC-DM1 (super duper Herceptin) versus Capecitabine (Xeloda) + Lapatinib (Tykerb).  At least I can still use my nifty new port for Aredia (the trial drugs are all oral).  What sucks is that it may take 1-2 months to get my tissue samples from Boston.  But my onc there can move mountains so if required, I'll give her a call.  I'm worried about how much more cancer can pop up while I wait for the trial.  If so much showed up in 1 month...how much in another couple of months? I think I've been spending too much time in DeNile.  My onc said that Taxol and Gemzar bought me a year, the trial will hopefully buy me another.  Huh.  I really wasn't thinking in year blocks of time yet.  This puts a whole new spin on things.  Maybe I should go on disability and move into some crap apartment.  But then, work can be fun.  I need to think about this.  But first a nap and then sulking.  Can I have a hug?  Anyone? Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Elizabeth's Mets: Liver, bones, brain (yuck), and lungs (more yuck). Dx 5/2007, ILC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 13/19 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Progression in liver and bones :-( konakat dreamwriter

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2010 09:57AM - edited Jan 20, 2010 08:45AM by konakat I'm thinking of getting in contact with the local humane society.  Now that I can't afford monthly donations I can certainly give my time.  When I was young I used to think it would be cool, if I was every diagnosed as terminal, to take a harpoon for a whale (i.e., like take a bullet, save the whale).  A kind of noble way to go out.  But I'm reconsidering, I might not have the energy to leap out of the boat in the nick of time to save it's life. So something where I can use my office and biz skills to help out.  Or maybe find a smaller, reputable animal or environment-related organization that could use the help.  Or maybe get back into art -- I used to throw pottery (might not be able to do that with my back) and make mosaics (yah, I play with broken glass!!).  The silver lining would be doing something I didn't think I could do before.  Or bother to take the time to do.  Something just for me.  That's all.  I am fully planted in reality though...I'd never be one of those annoying rah-rah positive people, you can count on that!!  The silver lining can be as simple as sleeping in (with a contented, smug smile as people crawl out of bed for work), a margarita for breakfast maybe!  Little delights amid the sludge of reality.  :-)

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2010 07:16AM - edited Jan 20, 2010 07:19AM by konakat I edited the post, hopefully clarified -- I don't want anyone else to think I'd harm a whale!!  Whaling is so horrible -- research my *ss -- what a joke that they make this claim!  About 6 years ago when I was in Australia and reading the Sydney newspaper I saw a cute ad from Greenpeace.  I think I still have it.  It was about including Greenpeace in your will, because "you never know if you'll come back as a whale!"  I thought that was great! Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2008 05:04PM konakat wrote: Thank-you all for the warm welcome. Shrink -- I'm in the same node boat as you -- 20 or so nodes were cancerous.  I was quite worried when a lot of women on the message boards were reporting only a few positive nodes.  And the liver mets.  However, everything seems to have been zapped this time around.  When the liver mets was confirmed I asked my onc if I am going to drop dead sooner than later and should I do all those things I want to do now.  She said "don't sell the barn yet" (I'm blunt so she is in response, she's a blast, so nice) and then listed off about 10 more chemo drugs to use if and when it returns and if what worked this time doesn't work any more.  I'm quite positive and I am very positive for you too!  Congrats on the clear scans!!  Sure, it's going to be in the back of my mind, but I am assuming I am OK. Re. effexor -- I take 300 mg -- been on it for years for panic attacks.  One friend who took it because of some thankfully temporary depression went up to 125 mg.  I believe 37.5 is the lowest dose. I started the Biotin -- my hair is thickening up -- probably just time having an effect, too soon to tell if it's the biotin.  I gave myself a little trim around the ears Sat night so that's a major milestone.  Now I just need to get some styling gel to practice taming the hair monster before I unleash it to public viewing the end of the month. And skinny jeans Shrink!!  I was so expecting to drop pounds on chemo but I put on 15 pounds -- I think it was mostly because every chemo eve I had cake or ice cream for dinner as a treat / comfort food.  So I'm trying to widdle that down...

I guess it's a moot point that I don't get Gemzar anymore...  The exciting thing is that I am being considered for a trial.  Comparison of Trastuzumab-MCC-DM1 (super duper Herceptin) versus Capecitabine (Xeloda) + Lapatinib (Tykerb).  At least I can still use my nifty new port for Aredia (the trial drugs are all oral).  What sucks is that it may take 1-2 months to get my tissue samples from Boston.  But my onc there can move mountains so if required, I'll give her a call.  I'm worried about how much more cancer can pop up while I wait for the trial.  If so much showed up in 1 month...how much in another couple of months? I think I've been spending too much time in DeNile.  My onc said that Taxol and Gemzar bought me a year, the trial will hopefully buy me another.  Huh.  I really wasn't thinking in year blocks of time yet.  This puts a whole new spin on things.  Maybe I should go on disability and move into some crap apartment.  But then, work can be fun.  I need to think about this.  But first a nap and then sulking.  Can I have a hug?  Anyone? Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Elizabeth's Mets: Liver, bones, brain (yuck), and lungs (more yuck). Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2009 01:39AM konakat wrote: The side effects all depended on which chemo.  Taxol was awful -- the aches and neuropathy.  I just took pain killers when it was bad.  It also affected my blood counts but to counteract that I got Neupogin shots.  My onc eventually stopped it -- the side effects were taking too much of a toll on my body even though the chemo was working. Right now I'm on Gemzar and it is a dream -- no side effects other than my platelets get low and I sometimes have to skip a chemo.  I wish all chemos were as gentle. So, as you said, if it comes to it, there is chemo.  But since you are doing fine now it's wonderful!!  Hugs, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2011 06:29PM - edited Mar 12, 2011 06:29PM by konakat If the pain persists you should see your onc.  It could be (but not necessarily) bone mets caused.  Quite possibly not mets related, but I thought I'd throw in my experience. I had a compression fracture in my spine and some thinning vertebra which screwed up a nerve and resulted in leg problems.  It was fixed with one radiation session. Heating pads are great.  The only painkiller that works on my bone pains are anti-inflammatories (like ibuprofen).  Codeine and morphine don't work for me -- strange, yet true!

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2010 08:38PM - edited Jan 26, 2010 08:39PM by konakat I have liver and bone mets and found Gemzar very easy -- no pain, no nausea, kept my hair.  It does wreak havoc on your platelets but that can be managed by decreasing the dose.  I started taking it last May (to replace Taxol because of its SEs). It was working very slowly and I did reduce my liver mets to just 1 lesion in November (bones cleared with Taxol).  Then my Dec scans showed 3 liver mets and even more bone mets.  It stopped working, probably in the fall when my blood work started to get bad but the mets were still too small to show up in my Nov scan. :-(   I still love Gemzar because it is so gentle.  And there are other women here having success with it.  I'd say go for it.

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2010 03:09PM - edited Feb 23, 2010 03:11PM by konakat Hi Flachica -- when I first started chemo for my liver mets my onc warned me that my liver twinges might increase even though the chemo was working.  That didn't happen for me (twinges stopped as lesions went away) but it apparently does happen for enough patients that she mentioned it.  So, it could very well be the chemo working -- the drugs you're on are very good and powerful for fighting liver mets.  On the other hand, an increase of twinges could mean the mets are coming back, as it did for me.  I know, crappy answer, but assume the chemo is working until told otherwise.  Since you're on such good drugs I would assume you will get a good scan.  Let us know what you find out.  Hugs, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2008 11:10AM konakat wrote: Cripes -- I just found this group too  -- I started chemo in June 07.  I wish the most recent posting were at the top!!  I thought it was all "old" postings. Here's the background -- lumpectomy in May, A/C June and July.  Margin cleanup August.  Taxol (oooh, the pain, eventually had to go on oxycontin!!), now have only 6 rads left (of 33).  Very red boob, crispy clavicle (yuck).  And I'm obsessing about my hair. Oh yeah, a couple of weeks ago it was confirmed that I had mets to my liver but the chemo cleared it up -- it's gone...  My big problem is that I never told my Mom.  I haven't been back home since Feb 07 (I moved from Canada to the US Nov 06) and keep telling her work is keeping me too busy.  It has been the lack of hair that has kept me away -- wouldn't be able to hide that!!  She's bought it so far.  She's in her 80's, a terrible worrier and starting a bit of Alzhiemers but still pretty sharp and simply a lovely woman.  Anyway... I always remember her saying she would drop dead if anything happened to one of her kids -- hence me not telling her.  My sister, an MD, at first said I should tell her but then agreed that it is better that I don't give my Mom that sadness and grief.  Even though I'm 45 years old, there are days I would just love to crawl into her arms and cry.  My hair is slowly growing -- and am finally visiting her the first weekend of Feb.  The story is that my goofy short hair is all the style and I just got a bad haircut. Has anyone been in this situation of trying to hide their cancer?  It's awful -- wanting to see my Mom but not being able to. Sorry for the long-winded posting -- wish I found you all earlier...

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 09:26AM konakat wrote: Hi Amontro, Breast cancer is incurable, whatever stage.  There are rare instances when a Stage IV woman goes into remission (no evidence of disease/NED) for many years.  The scary statistic is that only about 20% reach the 5 year mark after being diagnosed as Stage IV.  However, there's no reason that you shouldn't assume that you are in that lucky 20% and may life quite a number of years. It is wonderful that Herceptin is working so well for you!  I do hope it continues for a long time.  But more often than not, the cancer will spread.  However (again), every woman is different, there isn't a hard and fast rule.  Always go on the assumption that you will keep living until you are told otherwise.  Best wishes, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2010 12:02PM - edited Jan 24, 2010 12:03PM by konakat In the Palliative Forum there's a thread titled "Facing the Future" that has some ideas. I think the first thing to take care of is a will.  Do you have any special legal instructions re. your children?  Also a power of attorney for your finances (if applicable) and most importantly for someone to make medical choices on your behalf and ensure that your wishes are being followed if you are unable to communicate them yourself.  I've gone through all my photos and selected ones that best represent my life, what I've done and will put them in a scrapbook for my Mom (I don't have children).  I like the idea of scrapbooks, handwritten letters, anything that is tactile.  I like your idea of special messages -- your children's wedding day, first child.   Getting these things done gives me a sense of peace so I can continue on enjoying life -- like Janis, I don't intend to leave quite yet!  If I suddenly take a turn for the worse at least I don't have to scramble to do what I want re. messages, etc.  Hugs, Elizabeth xoxoxooo

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2010 07:16AM konakat wrote: Leprechaun -- A will isn't mandatory but if your wife has any assets of her own it would probably help move things along to go into your name.  So as to not upset your wife, perhaps you could ask a lawyer for advice on if it is mandatory, particularly if all your assets are jointly shared.  Things like insurance policies don't need a will.  When my father died my Mom was able to get the money immediately.  But he did have a will for assets not in my Mom's name -- I assume it sped things along during probate.  Still, I'd ask a lawyer if you can avoid it.

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2010 09:53AM konakat wrote: Lisa -- I had all my scans (2 years worth!) on CD so the Ottawa radiologist could take a look.  What was interesting is that when he reviewed my Nov scan he was able to barely pick up mets on my sternum that was missed in the Nov report.  This is the 2nd time I've had someone review an older scan and see a teeny smudge that in hindsight was actually teeny mets.  I'm only going to Boston to visit, not see docs.  I wouldn't be able to pay them anyway if they had a look.  I have aches and pains in all the right spots though -- they match up where the mets are. Thank-you for the gourmand tips Tami!  I'll try the wine you suggested.  Baking?  Is that when you mix stuff up and put it in the frozen pizza thawing appliance?  I tried to bake a cake once and it came out as brownies -- kinda heavy, yet yummy...  I'll write down the recipe anyway -- just in case I feel adventurous! On Thursday the social worker asked what makes me so resilient.  I didn't have an answer.  But then this morning I figured it out.  I have no husband/partner (b/f in Boston doesn't count -- see him once a month, questionable commitment on his part), no kids, no career -- nothing that sends me into a panic if I die.  I do have my old geriatric cat though, she keeps me going.  I need to find something that gets me excited about life.  It sure helps having this thread -- I don't feel as alone.  Still not crying...geesh.

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 01:33PM konakat wrote: PET scans can give false positives. Every PET I ever had was followed up by a CT or MRI to confirm the results.  Also, it is recommended that no strenuous exercise be done the day or so before the PET - this may have contributed to your wife's false positive.  The MRI should provide you with a definitive answer.  I hope you get the scan soon so you and your wife can be assured that it was a false positive and that she is fine.  Wishing you all the best, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 11:31AM - edited Feb 21, 2011 11:32AM by konakat Amontro -- please don't make any hasty, life-changing decisions.  I'm just guessing, but you are having to deal with what your onc said (and our posts) and it may colour your decisions right now.  Maybe wait a while and discuss this with your psychologist.  You could very well be jumping the gun and not have to make these decisions for quite a while. You certainly could post your questions in this Stage IV forum -- I'm sure there are other women that can relate to what you're going through.  Also the Depression, Anxiety and Post Traumatic Stress Disorder board might be a place to post too. In any case, I hope you find solutions that are the best ones for you.  Hugs, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2010 11:34AM konakat wrote: I think how you approach your sister's friend depends on how well you know her friend.  If you don't know her or are only an acquaintance I wouldn't take the first step.  I had a friend who wanted to put me in touch with all these people she knew had BC and I wasn't interested.  If you don't have a close relationship with the friend it might be a good idea that your sister ask her if she'd like to get in contact with you.  Keep in mind that sometimes when you're feeling like crap the last thing you want to do is feel obligated to make nice with a stranger.  Or maybe she will welcome it -- who knows, everyone is different. If you are friends with her, what was already mentioned here sounds good.  If not, let your sister be the bridge between you and her friend and let her friend decide if she wants to make contact.

Posts.Content: konakat wrote: Well, I wasn't expecting the news I got today.  I was scanned up the kazoo (figuratively, not literally, haha) in November and there was just my usual one stubborn liver lesion.  Same old, same old.  I was expecting the same thing today from the results of my December scans.  In one month the cancer roared back.  Two new lesions on my liver (plus my old one), old spine lesion back, and new ones on my sternum, and a suspicious blip on my hipbone.  And a suspicious blip on my lung.  Kinda explains why my back has started to hurt again.  And stupid me, I thought the pain in my right side was just poor posture from being a couch potato.  Interesting how the mind can blank out the obvious. I guess it's a moot point that I don't get Gemzar anymore...  The exciting thing is that I am being considered for a trial.  Comparison of Trastuzumab-MCC-DM1 (super duper Herceptin) versus Capecitabine (Xeloda) + Lapatinib (Tykerb).  At least I can still use my nifty new port for Aredia (the trial drugs are all oral).  What sucks is that it may take 1-2 months to get my tissue samples from Boston.  But my onc there can move mountains so if required, I'll give her a call.  I'm worried about how much more cancer can pop up while I wait for the trial.  If so much showed up in 1 month...how much in another couple of months? I think I've been spending too much time in DeNile.  My onc said that Taxol and Gemzar bought me a year, the trial will hopefully buy me another.  Huh.  I really wasn't thinking in year blocks of time yet.  This puts a whole new spin on things.  Maybe I should go on disability and move into some crap apartment.  But then, work can be fun.  I need to think about this.  But first a nap and then sulking.  Can I have a hug?  Anyone? Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Elizabeth's Mets: Liver, bones, brain (yuck), and lungs (more yuck). Dx 5/2007, ILC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 13/19 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 13, 2010 07:38PM konakat wrote: Hi Kccatz -- welcome to Club Mets, and sorry you have to be here.  I do understand your desire to throw everything and the kitchen sink at the cancer.  However, there are many women here who have beaten back the cancer for years on hormonals.  I can understand why some friends say "stay off the net".  There are predators out to take advantage of people with cancer (or whatever), offering false hope, bogus products, etc.  Definitely go to the reputable sites (i.e., those associated with a hospital, American Cancer Society, goverment, or are referenced by them).  You just need to weed out the crap.  Oh yeah, this site is the best -- good info that's easy to read and digest.  And best of all, the women here.  I couldn't get through this without them.  You will get lots of support here.  Hugs, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2011 06:58PM konakat wrote: Sometimes someone will start a thread with the subject "How are you doing ______?"  And in the text say you're thinking of them...  If she's feeling crappy it might cheer her up to know someone's thinking of her.  Or someone might reply to the thread with further news about her. I have my PMs set up so I get an email notice when I receive one.  Maybe she's set up like that too and will respond.  Give it a few days and if she doesn't respond maybe start a thread?  Last year when I was really sick I didn't go on the boards for ages.  The only way anyone knew I was still around was Sharon50 posting updates.  So if she doesn't respond, don't assume the worst. Another thing you can do is go to her profile page -- it will show if she's logged in and when the last time she did.  Maybe she just isn't posting much. Hope this helps. Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2009 11:58AM konakat wrote: Hi Robin -- this too has been in the back of my mind for quite a while.  I do now have a long distance thing with my b/f but never that nurturing, caring, loving relationship that I yearn for, even when we lived in the same city!  The singles thread has given me hope, that there are men out there who aren't freaked out by our lumpectomies, reconstructions, and flat chests.  But I don't know about being Stage IV, how they will react.  Sure, anyone can die, regardless of having cancer or not.  Men our age (40, 50+) are getting into the heart attack years.  So many questions -- will he hold back on love if he knows his heart will be broken sooner rather than later?  Will he treat us like a normal person or an invalid?  Will he just think of the "burden" towards the end?  I don't know.  I've been single all my life and I'd really like to have someone who loves me.  I don't think it's unfair to the man, if he knows and makes the choice for himself.  I do think it is unfair to ourselves if we don't pursue a relationship if we want one. I hope someone in our predicament posts.  Thanks for starting this thread Robin. Elizabeth xox

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2011 11:45PM konakat wrote: Awwwww Athena -- this was so sweet of you to do!  And all my friends who posted. Here's my trip report: It was 85 and sunny every day.  I lazed on the beach, drank, swam, and snorkled.  Every single day.  Each evening I hung out at the beach bar for more drinks and dinner.  I thought of doing some excursions but was too lazy. I only read one book -- spent the rest of the time observing people.  My first observation was that there were no decent cabana boys!  Yikes!!  I did not get laid!!!  I was so worried about disappointing you all!  The most excitement was gettting a pat down when I left the Caymans.  She did these gentle caresses, I got kinda turned on...  Huh. The beach was full of couples, some families, and dreaded honeymooners.  I positioned my lounger away from the masses so I wouldn't have to talk to anyone.  Most of the men were funny looking in their swimming trunks with the waistband down near their willy wonkas.  It was really weird that most of the women were thin, I could count vertebra and ribs.  Yikes!!  Some of them wore make-up and jewelry to the beach, hair sprayed to great big helmets. The funniest moment was when a bunch of people were on a banana boat ride and the back two fell off!!!  They were spotted and the boat pulling the banana turned around to get them.  Then another great guffaw watching them trying to get back on.  I'm so mean. This does sound like a really boring trip but all I really wanted and needed was to lounge on a beach and swim.  I did both everyday so it was great.  My camera died on me so I had to use my cell for photos.  Here's three: Me lounging on the beach (BTW it's a polynesian turtle tattoo on my ankle).  Beach without my legs:  View of resort's courtyard from my room's balcony.

Posts.Content: May 25, 2011 06:51AM konakat wrote: Hi Eric, Platelets are my nemeses.  I get more chemo appts cancelled than taken because of low platlets and knowing I am getting worse all the time. When I got an IV for a scan the other day by one of the really good techs IMO, I ended up with a black and blue bruise 5" x 3" at the injection site.  It's still there and quite a thing to behold.  I do understand your frustration!! Epogen, Procrit, and Aranasp are used to treat anemia/low red blood cells.  Pretty well it's time that eventually gets platelet numbers back up.  A transfusion of whole blood or platelets aren't really effective. Ask your oncs when they expect your platelets to rise up to suitable levels.  Could a lower dose of Abraxane help?  A change in chemo once your platelets are better?  Ask about getting rads for your back and other painful areas -- really helps. Wishing you luck, Elizabeth

Posts.Title: RESPECTING the STAGE threads **RANT** cherneski Nico1012

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2010 01:53PM - edited Feb 12, 2010 01:54PM by konakat Re. the "death vigils": I know every single post is written with a warm, caring heart.  Although I know they mean well, but praying for a cure is a bit inappropriate in vigil/death posts, IMHO.  A vigil thread is about the person dying, not BC in general (i.e., wishes for a cure).  A cure is not possible and won't happen for that person.  A cure and the hope for one is irrelevant and hasn't been in the cards for quite a while.  There will be no "miracles".  So, praying for a cure at that time really could be taken as an unintended slap in the face - i.e., too late for you but maybe there might be a cure for the rest of us.  I think posts on vigil/death threads should be focused on the person dying and their family (as they mostly are), not a place to express our wishes for a cure.  Please note: this is my opinion as a Stage IV person with a crappy prognosis and not meant to represent that of a group/Stage.  :-)

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2009 02:34PM - edited Jun 11, 2009 02:35PM by konakat You might think about bug spray -- you don't want a bunch of bites on your arm. For swimming I just used a head scarf and when it got wet it stayed snug on my head.  Wet knots are hard to come undone and when the material's wet it sticks to your head.  You can make it your vacation style statement by having a selection of scarves.  If it's humid be sure to take your sleeve.  Even before lymphedema my arms used to swell in the head and humidity.  I didn't wear it to the beach because I was to vain, so I did exercises each evening to get the lymph flowing and then wore my sleeve.  But being on the water and cruise you probably won't have too much of a problem -- the cooling effect of the ocean. Have a wonderful vacation! Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2010 05:11PM - edited Feb 23, 2010 05:12PM by konakat I think you can struggle on for years with a crappy QOL, it doesn't mean the end is near.  It all depends on each person's individual values on what QOL means.  It can come to the point where you have to ask yourself if your QOL is so crappy that continuing treatment isn't worth it.  That will be the hardest decision in our lives to make -- but I think we will know deep down when it's time.  If there is even a small doubt about stopping treatment it isn't time.  I think we'll know.  The women who have posted that they decided to end treatment have achieved such an amazing peace with their decision.

Posts.Content: May 13, 2009 06:19PM konakat wrote: The steroid I got was Decadron and it is used to combat allergic reactions to the chemo.  For me it did cause the munchies and sleeplessness a bit.  I put on 10 pounds but a lot was from the comfort food I was eating -- too much cake.  Some people lose weight, others stay the same -- there doesn't seem to be a hard and fast rule. With the Cytoxan and Adriamycin (often shortened as AC in the posts here) there is nausea, but you will be given meds for that.  If what they give you doesn't work well enough, be sure to tell them and they will give you something else. And drink lots of water. Yes, it's really overwhelming -- sort of like being in a bad dream.  But you get in a rhythm and you get through it.  The key is to always tell the nurse how you feel.  It took a bit of time for me to get over the feeling of complaining, but be vocal.  They want to know how you feel and will help you.  A good place to read up about the drugs is: http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/druginformation.html There are some short forms used in the posts here -- now that you know about the AC one you should be able to browse the posts for some more info.  Sometimes you'll see TAC -- that's AC and a drug Taxol or Taxotere that often follows AC.  Yeah, this sucks.  This website and community is very helpful -- ask questions anytime.  I wish you all the best as you get through your chemo. Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2010 09:18PM konakat wrote: Hi Michel -- I haven't been on either chemo yet but others have had good results with them.  Re. vitamins etc., ask your Mom's nurse or social worker at the hospital to schedule an appointment with a dietician or other specialist they have on staff for complementary treatments.  Please make sure whomever she consults is affiliated with your Mom's cancer clinic or hospital.  It is critical that any supplements etc. she takes do not interfere with the chemo or cause a life-threatening reaction.  And be sure that the specialist is knowledgeable about oncology and chemotherapy regimes.  Good luck! Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2010 03:22PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:53AM by konakat When I was in really bad shape my bilrubin got up to 90umol/L (normal is 0 to 20 umol/L or 0.174 to 1.04 mg/dL) and I was really yellow!  My other liver numbers were 5-10 times the normal.  GGT maxed out at 1800 (normal 12-43). Yikes! I've been on navelbine and carboplatin for about 2 months now -- liver numbers close to normal or double, GGT still 1500 but I guess that is just reflecting how damaged my liver is.  BTW -- navelbine didn't help much, it was the addition of carboplatin that I finally started to get some good results.  So, even if your Mom's numbers are really high now, hitting on the right treatment can really help.  I hope carbo is the one that helps your Mom.

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2009 05:10PM konakat wrote: Hi GScott -- Mom will be 84 tomorrow!! Here's what I found that may be useful to you: Here's a link to Cornell University http://envirocancer.cornell.edu/FactSheet/Diet/fs44.survival.cfm to a fact sheet titled "Diet and Lifestyle and Survival from Breast Cancer".  I thought it might be of interest because it includes diet and enviornmental info.  Here's the first paragraph: The current five-year survival rate for women with breast cancer is 86%. (The survival rate is the percentage of women who are still living a period of time after they are diagnosed with breast cancer.) The current ten-year survival rate is 76%. These rates include women at all stages or levels of severity of breast cancer. Women with cancer that has not metastasized - that is, the cancer has not moved to the lymph system or other parts of the body - have a five-year survival rate of 96%. Women whose breast cancer has metastasized to other parts of the body have a five-year survival rate of 21%. From the American Cancer Society http://www.cancer.org/docroot/stt/stt_0.asp?from=fast -- scroll down and on the bottom right you'll find a link to Breast Cancer stats.  They also have a section on Complementary and Alternative Methods http://www.cancer.org/docroot/CRI/content/CRI_2_4_4X_Complementary_and_Alternative_Methods_5.asp?rnav=cri -- towards the bottom there is a list of questions to consider to evaluate alternative sites.  Here's that UK website I mentioned earlier:  http://info.cancerresearchuk.org/cancerstats/types/breast/.  It also has a section on understanding stats http://www.cancerhelp.org.uk/help/default.asp?page=155&order=57 Medscape has a resource center with info from scientific journals.  You do have to create an account but it's free.  http://www.medscape.com/resource/breastcancer I think you will find much more accurate and encouraging information from these sites.  Take care. Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2010 09:12PM - edited Jan 23, 2010 09:16PM by konakat I think it would be a great idea to see the nutritionist or dietician at the hospital.  Then you can be sure your Mom gets all the nutrients she needs and nothing that interferes with her chemo.  Just like Terri said, get organic if you can.  Fresh foods as opposed to canned or processed.  Frozen veggies are supposed to hold their nutrients as well as fresh though.  Steamed or raw is better than boiled -- it leaches out the nutrients.  The nutritionist/dietician at the hospital can probably create a good plan for your Mom and also recommend some books.  Good luck! Elizabeth Just thought of this:  A book that was recommended by my hospital's social worker and many women here is Anti-Cancer, A New Way Of Life by David Servan-Schreiber.

Posts.Content: Jul 29, 2009 10:52AM konakat wrote: Hi Bette -- so sorry about the news.  I find it helpful esp with the timelines.  When I was put on taxol I was told I would be on it until I got good results.  That was too vague for me so I asked when the next test would be done to check progress.  I found it a lot more manageable to have the tx chunked up into blocks of time. Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2010 04:59PM konakat wrote: Hi Karen -- sorry you had to join us, but welcome. I'm on Navelbine (with Carbo and Zometa) right now.  Navelbine is quite gentle -- I am a bit queasy on the day I get it, but 1 zofran the day of my infusion takes care of it.  I did have some hair thinning though, but not so bad that I had to wear a scarf or wig.  However, Navelbine (a.k.a. Navy Bean) has another nickname -- Navelbind -- you can get some pretty wicked constipation (i.e., bound up).  Sennekot can help out.  I also take daily Colace (natural, keeps the you-know-what from drying out into hard rocks).  If I don't take the Colace every day I'm in deep doo-doo (pun intended).  I also take prescription Lactulose.  None of these meds interfere with one another so you can mix and match. I haven't taken Xeloda but have heard that it can he painful on the hands and feet.  You should avoid hot water on them and use lots of lotion like Respin said. Good luck! ELizabeth

Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2009 07:01AM konakat wrote: Awareness is good, but a lot of the hoopla about early detection makes it sound that BC is curable.  Not too big a worry, you'll be fine.  Ha!  When I was first dx-ed with BC I thought it was going to be OK, I'll get through it with treatment and that would be that.  Big ha! I'm mixed with all the pink stuff.  If it brings a few more pennies to research good.  But the companies are getting good publicity (aren't they nice thinking about BC!) and a tax deduction.  I just wish it spent more time on promoting research instead of implying that if you are "aware" you reduce or are not at risk. Since being dx-ed I haven't worn a pink ribbon.  I am a walking "pink ribbon" and getting the message out with my big mouth.  People who know I have cancer (and those who don't too) look at me funny if I don't donate money.  I just tell them I've done better -- I've offered up my body for clinical trials -- if I can get on one I know I am really helping my BC sisters now and those in the future.

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2010 02:23PM konakat wrote: Forget about the housework -- get someone in for that, or get your DH to do it.  He needs to step up to the plate.  Perhaps he's worried and just by avoiding you he's trying to avoid your illness.  Well buster -- now's the time to show what kind of man he is and be a proper husband. I understand it driving you crazy being stuck in bed when it is so very much against your nature.  What does your onc think?  Is there a more gentle chemo that could do the job?  How about a chemo break to get your strength up for your surgery and get your strength up in general then get back on the taxotere?  For the emotional side of things, if you can swing it, how about a weekend stay in a swanky hotel, room service, get your hair done -- a change of scenery and some pampering?  You definitely need a pick-me-up.  I am very sorry you're going through such a rough time -- physically and emotionally.  Both can hurt so much.  I've offered a few thoughts that might help you sort out what you want to do.  I don't know which is worse, too many choices or not enough.  I really wish I had a solution, something wise to say but I don't.  But I can offer a hug. Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2009 07:06PM konakat wrote: Hi Jan -- it must be especially hard when you are so young.  It's just not fair.  We have been cheated.  I'm in my 40s and been stage IV for 2.5 years and I still feel cheated too.  Sometimes I get angry just looking at strangers going about their business, seemingly not a care in the world.  I feel cheated when I think about my friends planning things, enjoying their life, even getting upset about usual life things.  I'm envious of everyone but me having a "normal" life.  I don't think I'll ever get over feeling cheated and envious.  But then I'm somewhat mentally prepared for dying, better equiped for some of life's tragedy.  I feel I have a wisdom that my peers do not.  Almost like I know a secret that they do not -- it's hard to explain, some weird feeling I have.  Still, big whoopie-doo.  So, yes, I know what you mean by cheated.  And it's not fair.  I don't know if you'll get over it, but you might get used to it.  Hugs, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2009 12:15AM - edited Sep 10, 2009 12:19AM by konakat How someone is treated depends on their diagnosis -- some get chemo first, others go the hormonal route.  From what I've read, if someone's estrogen + (i.e., can use hormonal drugs) and the cancer isn't in an organ, they often try hormonal treatments first.  It is gentler on your body so that's a good thing.  Your oncologist may have been waiting to hear how the radiation went before deciding on the treatment with hormonal drugs.  I don't have an answer on why they aren't doing surgery. You or your Mom should ask for her oncologist about the choice in treatment to put your mind at ease.  After a few months on treatment her oncologist will order more tests to see how the treatment is working. Still, ask questions on what your Mom's treatment choices were based on. Your Mom probably will be given Zometa too  -- an IV drug that is used to strengthen her bones in addition to the hormonal treatment.  I do not think this is something that you should worry about, it sounds like she is getting a standard treatment for her bone mets.  Still, I would ask the doctor about the surgery.  I'm sure some more bone mets sisters will chime in with their treatments and advice too.  Take care, and please ask any questions that you may have. Elizabeth

At first it bugged me that my ovaries were gone -- I joked that I was now spayed like my cats.  But it only lasted a short time -- I don't feel any different, only better.  It really never enters my mind.  And Lovinmomma is right about the brain being the biggest girl part -- love that!!!!

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2011 06:58PM konakat wrote: When I was on Gemzar I had a weird flare in my liver numbers for 2 weeks and then it simmered down.  My onc told me that our liver is a very sensitive organ.  We decided that it was caused by me painting my house at the time -- the fumes got to me (and my liver). Also, so I wouldn't get crappy numbers, I never had a glass of wine (or whatever) within 2 days of my labs.  And try avoid tylenol products if you can -- tylenol is very hard on the liver.  And drink lots of water to flush your system. I hope some of this helps -- and that your liver gets with the program and settles down!

Posts.Title: CT Results dreamwriter Anne45

Posts.Content: konakat wrote: RANT!! Was I pissed off when I went to pick up my scan results.  First, the chest CT wasn't written up yet.  Second, the abdominal/pelvic one was but it was the sh*ttiest report I've ever seen!!  WTF!!!!  I could have written a more detailed one without even seeing the scan!  For example: Boney disease is noted - no sh*t Sherlock!!!  Details please!!!  So I ranted and raged to my nurse and McDreamy about the incompetence of the radiologist. Now for the oops: While I'm hissing and spitting, McDreamy points out that the scan says I've improved!  Huh?!? What?  Ooooooh.  Seems like I missed out on some stuff while ranting.  The scan impression said that "it was somewhat difficult to assess measurable disease in this particular case.  In comparison with the previous examination of Dec 2010, there is considered further improvement."  Only 2 lesions are visible, having shrunk from 6.3 to 3.7 and 4.8 to 4.2 cm since December.  Still have some ascites though. This explains why there wasn't as much to report - I'm getting a bit better. Silly me. Still, no bone info.  I'll get an x-ray to see if anything jumps out since my bones really hurt.  Maybe there will be more in the chest scan -- my ribs are killing me. McDreamy said he looked at the chest CT and didn't see any lesions in my lungs.  Ooooooh.  That's good. So, liver and lungs improving.  Bones to be determined.  I keep on the same chemo since it's working. Stupider me: Well, well, well, maybe the brain rads has affected my cognitive ability.  While we were discussing some chemo scheduling snafus I kept saying huh, what?  I couldn't get it though my head what McDreamy was saying.  It took 3 repetitions for me to understand something simple!!  Also he noticed that my hearing is worse too.  I'm supposed to wear hearing aids (had them for over 5 years) but I can't stand all the background noise so I rarely wear them.  How do you normal hearing people stand it?  Anyway, it's worse but it's no big deal to me, just more peace and quiet for me. So that's the latest scoop.  I should be happy but I know it won't last.  And there's still that pesky leptomenigeal mets...don't know if the rads worked until June.  I'm still grumpy and pessimistic. Stupider me: Well, well, well, maybe the brain rads has affected my cognitive ability.  While we were discussing some chemo scheduling snafus I kept saying huh, what?  I couldn't get it though my head what McDreamy was saying.  It took 3 repetitions for me to understand something simple!!  Also he noticed that my hearing is worse too.  I'm supposed to wear hearing aids (had them for over 5 years) but I can't stand all the background noise so I rarely wear them.  How do you normal hearing people stand it?  Anyway, it's worse but it's no big deal to me, just more peace and quiet for me. So that's the latest scoop.  I should be happy but I know it won't last.  And there's still that pesky leptomenigeal mets...don't know if the rads worked until June.  I'm still grumpy and pessimistic. Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Elizabeth's Mets: Liver, bones, brain (yuck), and lungs (more yuck). Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2010 02:53PM - edited Feb 21, 2010 02:56PM by konakat I wore the wig in my avatar.  If you get one with long bangs it's not as noticable when your eyebrows disappear.  I was a consultant at the time and didn't want them to know about my BC or freak them out.  It was a very inexpensive wig -- the first "good" one I had had too much hair, even after the stylist thinned it out multiple times.  At home either bald or my skull and crossbones bandana. TIP:  I got a great tip on this site.  Even though I took the shears to my head before my hair came out there were still lots of little tiny hairs that shed over the weeks.  The tip is to use a lint roller on your head -- it picks up those little hairs, and gave me a laugh each morning when I rolled my head!

I am amazed by what others can do -- still work, take care of their family.  The first 2 years of bc/Stage IV I worked fulltime -- don't know how I did it.  Last year I'd throw a party for 40-50 guests every month, often the day after chemo.  Now, I'm old and decrepit at 48.  My brain would like to work but my body doesn't.   I'm contemplating on getting someone in to clean for me -- it hurts and tires me so much just to clean my tiny bathroom.  It's hard seeing my friends having full lives while I kinda just exist.  You're definitely not alone in this.  Good thing to vent.  I also appreciate the opportunity to tag on my vent in your thread.  Hugs.
Posts.Title: Ability to do what you used too do. pee pee

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2009 07:19PM konakat wrote: Hi Carla -- Depression is awful -- few people understand it if it hasn't happened to them.  Logic (i.e., desire to live for DH and children, hobbies, etc.) and depression (life and mets are unbearable) often conflict, and all too often depression is the winner in that battle.  Just like you said, you know you don't want to die, but you have these feelings of unbearable pain.  I absolutely understand what you're saying. So, if I were you, the first thing I'd do is get that Effexor dose increased, doubled!  75mg isn't very much.  I've been on anti-depressants for many years, including Effexor.  My Effexor was at 300mg but is now at 150mg.  Address the chemical stuff behind depression first -- it's a quick (sort of) fix.  Then if there are situational things (i.e., liver mets, (yeah, no kidding), or whatever else is going on with your life) work on those with your therapist.  You can come back from depression Carla.  It can be a take 2 steps forward, 1 step back kind of thing, but you can do it.  Once you get some relief with Effexor, you can then work on the other stuff.  The Effexor will give you that little boost to make all the other stuff more manageable. And promise me, if you do think you are going to take your life, please get to a hospital.  Please.  You can get through this.  You really can.  With hugs and understanding, Elizabeth xox

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2010 09:29AM - edited Jan 3, 2010 09:30AM by konakat I LOVE Gemzar.  My hair was growing back thick from Taxol and continues to grow. No thinning for me!  Yay!!  No aches, no nausea, no nuthin'.  It can make your platelets tank so your Mom's onc will play with the dose (i.e.,reduce it) or give it to her less often.  I've been on it since May and wish all chemos were like Gemzar.  One thing is that I found it is slow to work, but it does -- I had 7 liver lesions and one on my spine last January, now I only have one stubborn one left on my liver.  It is a nice break from the side effects that I used to get on all the other chemos.  I think your Mom will be relieved to be switched to Gemzar. Elizabeth xox

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2011 08:05PM konakat wrote: I've had a couple of occasions where the BC sped up and hip hopped everywhere.  But it can be beaten back.  Please do not dispair too much with this latest setback.  You can clobber the BC again. Re.: time.  Just over a year ago I moved back to Ottawa, got an apt downtown so I could walk to work, just carry on as usual.  Then I spoke to the hospital's social worker.  She asked me, do I want to keep working for as long as I can drag myself into the office, or do I want to use the benefits available to not work and have the time do whatever I wanted.  Huh, didn't think of that option.  So I went on permanent disability; it felt like a luxury even though the money is a fraction of what I made.  I do miss work and the camaraderie, but not the way time whizzed by.  Time passes so much slower now, no deadlines racing towards me.  I can do whatever I feel like.  Katie's idea of giving it a trial run is excellent.  It was a bit of a shock to my system not working, but overall I am happy with my decision.  Since time is on your mind, perhaps you should go on leave.  It would be worse if you didn't and wished that you had.  You can't get lost time back.

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2009 05:36AM konakat wrote: Re the ER+ thing -- some tumors aren't 100% ER+.  For example, when first dx-ed my pathology said 68% ER+.  I understand this as meaning 68% of the cells will respond to hormonal treatment and the other 32% won't so you have to attack them with something else.  I'm borderline Heu/2+ -- so again I think herceptin only works a bit for me -- I did get a mets recurrance while on Herceptin.  But I'm still on Herceptin because I am getting some benefits. I never think it as time lost, always time gained since I'm still alive and there are still treatments.  Of course, you caught me here on a good day!  Many times I've been told to think of BC as a nasty chronic disease -- you keep treating it as you would any other chronic disease.  There are many women here that are NED for years -- either from a successful chemo or while on hormonals.  Being stable is good too.  If you get progression you kick it back with a new treatment.  Yeah, we keep on -- we are fighters.  Stronger that we ever dreamed we could be.  Growl.

Posts.Content: konakat wrote: RANT!! Was I pissed off when I went to pick up my scan results.  First, the chest CT wasn't written up yet.  Second, the abdominal/pelvic one was but it was the sh*ttiest report I've ever seen!!  WTF!!!!  I could have written a more detailed one without even seeing the scan!  For example: Boney disease is noted - no sh*t Sherlock!!!  Details please!!!  So I ranted and raged to my nurse and McDreamy about the incompetence of the radiologist. Now for the oops: While I'm hissing and spitting, McDreamy points out that the scan says I've improved!  Huh?!? What?  Ooooooh.  Seems like I missed out on some stuff while ranting.  The scan impression said that "it was somewhat difficult to assess measurable disease in this particular case.  In comparison with the previous examination of Dec 2010, there is considered further improvement."  Only 2 lesions are visible, having shrunk from 6.3 to 3.7 and 4.8 to 4.2 cm since December.  Still have some ascites though. This explains why there wasn't as much to report - I'm getting a bit better. Silly me. Still, no bone info.  I'll get an x-ray to see if anything jumps out since my bones really hurt.  Maybe there will be more in the chest scan -- my ribs are killing me. McDreamy said he looked at the chest CT and didn't see any lesions in my lungs.  Ooooooh.  That's good. So, liver and lungs improving.  Bones to be determined.  I keep on the same chemo since it's working. Stupider me: Well, well, well, maybe the brain rads has affected my cognitive ability.  While we were discussing some chemo scheduling snafus I kept saying huh, what?  I couldn't get it though my head what McDreamy was saying.  It took 3 repetitions for me to understand something simple!!  Also he noticed that my hearing is worse too.  I'm supposed to wear hearing aids (had them for over 5 years) but I can't stand all the background noise so I rarely wear them.  How do you normal hearing people stand it?  Anyway, it's worse but it's no big deal to me, just more peace and quiet for me. So that's the latest scoop.  I should be happy but I know it won't last.  And there's still that pesky leptomenigeal mets...don't know if the rads worked until June.  I'm still grumpy and pessimistic. Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2010 05:39PM konakat wrote: Hi SuzyQ, Some docs to surgery for Stage IV, others don`t.  There`s still debate on whether it is necessary for Stage IV.  I`d go with what my doc recommends.  If the main mass is responding to chemo they might not want to do surgery.  I can`t say for sure. It`s hard to predict what will happen. The cancer could respond and your sister end up cancer-free for years.  Or it may come back quickly.  It`s all a guessing game.  It can also take a few tries of different chemos to find one that works and works for a long time. It seems that responses to chemo are as individual as we each are.  Yah, sucks, but what can we do. You`re a good sister.  And please let us know how it goes.  Hugs, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: konakat wrote: RANT!! What?  Ooooooh.  Seems like I missed out on some stuff while ranting.  The scan impression said that "it was somewhat difficult to assess measurable disease in this particular case.  In comparison with the previous examination of Dec 2010, there is considered further improvement."  Only 2 lesions are visible, having shrunk from 6.3 to 3.7 and 4.8 to 4.2 cm since December.  Still have some ascites though. This explains why there wasn't as much to report - I'm getting a bit better. Silly me. Still, no bone info.  I'll get an x-ray to see if anything jumps out since my bones really hurt.  Maybe there will be more in the chest scan -- my ribs are killing me. So, liver and lungs improving.  Bones to be determined.  I keep on the same chemo since it's working. Your bone pain could be a combo of all the scans and Navelbine.  I hope it gets better.  A heating pad helps me a lot with back and hip pain.  Navelbine also tires me out -- when I get home I just flop into bed.  And, welcome to the wild and wacky world of constipation!  If it hasn't started yet, it will... The other day when I tried some morphine again I dreamt of bunnies (twitchy noses) and woke up with a finger up each nostril!  Yuck.  At least I wasn't barfing.  Sharon50 and I got into a debate on if it was a scratch or a pick, like that old Seinfeld episode.  Mine was definitely a scratch and a rub.
Posts.Title: Rant / Oops, some good news / I AM stupider! konakat hrf

Posts.Content: May 12, 2011 10:33PM konakat wrote: I'm probably going on chemo vacation for a short while.  Sounds good eh?  Well, it's not.  I couldn't get chemo again today -- my platelets only went up one point since last week.  Could have used at least 30 more points.  This turn of events even warranted a bonus visit from McDreamy.  We're going to try one more time next week but we're not hopeful since my body's just too worn out from all the chemo.  So, until I see him again in June I'm cut loose.  I'm scared shitless.  I'm running out of options.  I'm not ready to drop dead yet!  I sure hope my brain scan comes out good so I have a bit of a chance. I told Mom and she's horribly worried.  I feel terrible about that.  Boston Boy managed to work his magic -- had me laughing about 5 minutes into our call.  He can be such an ass in too many ways to count but he always comes through when I need it. The really good news is that I'm once again pain-free. I'm gulping Advils and have gone back on Tylenol 3. No itchy face and I feel fine. Monday when I see the pain guy I'll mention Oxy, Boswella, acupuncture...  See what he says. So, back to hiding from the world.  I might go shopping.  Thanks for all the support and encouragement.  Hopefully I'll have good news in the coming weeks.  With a new thread!

Posts.Content: May 20, 2011 08:02PM - edited May 20, 2011 08:06PM by konakat Hi! My pain is getting more manageable -- still need to tweak the dose so I'm not zoned out or in excruciating pain if I don't take the break-through meds soon enough.  We'll get it right soon. I get my transfusion on Sunday -- 2 bags and over 4 hours.  I've never had one before and it kinda freaks me out -- some stranger's icky goo in my veins.  I know it's safe, just icky.  This weekend in Canada is a long weekend (Victoria Day) and the unofficial kick-off for summer and gardening.  For a fun snack and to celebrate I'm thinking of bringing in tomato juice with celery sticks and little umbrellas and tell the other patients I'm getting the expedited version of the infusion.  I never drink clamato juice -- I feel sorry for the clams. My brain scan on Wed was very bizarre.  When I got up to walk to the table I got dizzy (like that's never happened before!) and hit the floor, in sweetie tech's arms. He said I had a seizure -- only lasted a few moments though.  I told him I didn't think so, I just passed out.  He countered by saying I was twitchy.  I replied that sometimes I twitch from dizziness.   I did crack him up when I said I was relieved that I had undies on with the way I was splayed out -- he doesn't get a peek without at least a drink first! What was weird was that everything went white around me just before it happened. When I woke up it felt like I had a long dream -- frolicking in the Caribbean.  My tech's from the Caribbean so that makes sense.  But it felt so long I was surprised that I was only out of it for a short while. It will be an interesting next few days.   I hope this "siezure" isn't a sign for what my scan results will be like.  Thanks for all of your support. Hugs, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2010 09:58AM konakat wrote: Hi ButterflyBonnie (love your name).  I did AC (then taxol) when I was first diagnosed -- I had liver mets from the beginning.  When I was scanned after the AC the liver mets were gone!  It's a hard chemo (hairloss and nausea) but well worth it.  Re. the cost of the meds -- ask your pharmacist if they have a less expensive generic brand.  Also check the website of the pharmaceutical company that makes the meds -- they might have financial assistance or a coupon for them.  Re. heart issues -- I never got a muga before AC and did fine.  Your onc is keeping a good eye on you so you should be fine too. Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2010 06:32AM - edited Mar 11, 2010 06:34AM by konakat Every time I started a new chemo I never got the Neulasta shot.  I'd get the bloodwork done before the 2nd (and subsequent) treatments, my WBCs would be low and then I'd get the Neulasta for the rest of the treatments.  I never clued in that it was probably an insurance thing -- that they wanted to see if you could do the chemo without it.  Also, maybe there is a medical protocol that it can't be prescribed unless there is proof in some bloodwork that it is needed.  Since you don't have that before you get your first treatment you don't get the shot.  This is just a guess on my part.

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2009 09:07PM - edited Nov 25, 2009 09:08PM by konakat Hi Helen, Yes there are anti-depressents that help -- the Effexor I take is for my depression and also for anxiety and panic attacks.  Carla's right -- get help with this.  We all have enough on our plate and should seek the help we need. Now is the time to really take care of ourselves, both physically and emotionally.  If the docs do suggest chemo, tell them you don't want to do taxol, there are some that are much more gentle -- Gemzar is one of them.  You keep your hair, no aches, no nausea -- I wish they all were like this! Think about giving your PCP a call on Friday or Monday to talk about this and get some anti-depressants to help take the edge off all you are going through.  Please take care of yourself. Elizabeth xox

Posts.Content: May 3, 2011 10:01PM konakat wrote: What's weird is that morphine did nothing for my bone pain when I tried it before.  Maybe I should give it another try tonight. So far I use a combo of Tylenol with codeine and plain old ibuprofen for inflammation.  If I don't take something every 3-4 hours it comes back so quickly -- I'm bent over or can't get out of a chair easily.  I was sure I had a ton of cracked ribs and nothing.  I'll have to talk to McDreamy more about this, especially about a patch.  That would be so much easier. I feel kinda whiny about this since there are others with worse pain.  A little pain is OK, reminds me that I'm alive.  If the bone mets are stablish, why all the pain?  Some bone repairing itself and other bones gettting bad? I'm getting everything x-rayed to see if there is something that should be radiated.  Gee, radiate all of me!  If I could just get this under control I might go out more often.  I haven't been out with my friends for months.  And go on a nice trip somewhere warm. For happy news, tomorrow I'm having dinner with Mom and then watching the Bruins game.  And getting my Easter candy!  Also taking Mom tons of flowers for Mother's Day. Thanks for all the warm thoughts and ideas to feel better.
