Posts.Content: May 4, 2011 11:45PM - edited May 4, 2011 11:46PM by konakat Well, poop.  I can't get chemo tomorrow (Thurs) because my platelets are too low.  It's been postponed until next week. I shouldn't be surprised -- I can rub a vein that was used weeks ago and make a bruise.  Cool, eh?  So Sharon and I will have to hang out another day. I had a great time with Mom.  She was sad to hear about my lungs but told her no worries, it will be my brain or liver that will get me in the end.  Didn't help that much, I wonder why...  We had a major oink-out.  And watched the Bruins.  And I came home with lots of leftovers, cupcakes, and my Easter chocolate -- chocolate truffle eggs and a bunny I can decapitate for breakfast tomorrow!!  Woohoo!!! Thanks for the hugs, they feel sooooooo good.
Posts.Title: Rant / Oops, some good news / I AM stupider! konakat hrf

Posts.Content: May 7, 2011 04:06PM konakat wrote: Mum sent me a t-shirt she got in Jamaica -- guess what "med" is on it.  Teehee! Re. platelets:  NSAIDS (anti-inflammatory painkillers) like Ibuprofen are very hard on platelets.  So is my chemo Navelbine.  Tylenol is OK and all the yummy opiates like Tylenol 3, morphine are OK too.  I sleep in 4 hour chunks now -- I wake up and take more Tylenol-3, go back to sleep.  I'm trying to ween off Ibuprofen since I seem to be missing one out of the two chemo sessions each month.  Blah.  But the tylenol 3 doesn't take care of what ibuprofen does.  Oh well....
Posts.Title: Rant / Oops, some good news / I AM stupider! konakat hrf

Posts.Content: May 10, 2011 05:50PM konakat wrote: What a difference new pain meds make!  I've been feeling horrible, felt like I had broken bones.  Today when I went for my labs I started whimpering and the nurse got my 2nd fav oncologist.  Since I was driving (bad me) I got 400mg of Ibuprofen to get me through the next few hours until I could get my new Codeine prescription filled.  Yum-yum.  I have it in 12-hour long lasting and regular codeine for break-through pain.  And I see a pain mgmt specialist on Monday.  I'll ask about the acupuncture too. And I found out that ibuprofen doesn't lower platelets, why was I told otherwise...  If you already have low platelets and get cut the ibuprofen hinders the clotting process.  Damn, I wish I knew that before.  But now I know it's only the Navelbine that's screwing up my platelets so if chemo's cancelled again this week what to do?  I want my chemo.  There aren't too many choices left. The best thing is the pain being managed.  I feel like a new person!!  To celebrate I got a new beach tote in anticipation of a trip!
Posts.Title: Rant / Oops, some good news / I AM stupider! konakat hrf

Posts.Content: May 11, 2011 11:54AM konakat wrote: I got 12-hour codeine and regular codeine that I can take every 2 hours.  Since it's not Tylenol-3 I can take it more often -- when it's hooked up with Tylenol you can only take it every 4 hours because Tylenol is hard on the liver, etc. Oh, yeah, the codeine didn't work very long.  I woke up frozen with pain at 2AM-ish.  It took me about 1.5 hours to psych myself up to move and actually get out of bed for more codeine.  I was feeling so good yesterday because the doc gave be a shitload of Ibuprofen -- that works for me.  So, as soon as the codeine kicks in a bit I'm going out to get some more ibuprofen/Advil (so stupid for not picking some up yesterday).  Can't wait until Monday to see the pain guy -- each day it's getting worse and worse.  At least I know it's possible to get pain free as long as some sort of NSAID is used. I haven't had chemo cancelled yet sooooo, hopefully it's a go for tomorrow.
Posts.Title: Rant / Oops, some good news / I AM stupider! konakat hrf

Posts.Content: May 11, 2011 05:05PM konakat wrote: Alpal -- I freaked when I saw mother or big sister.  Hehehe.  The ibuprofen will be fine -- it's what I was given yesterday at the clinic and it was heaven.  It will be OK.  I think it's unethical for my sis to call in a prescription.  I think I'm having ice cream for dinner!
Posts.Title: Rant / Oops, some good news / I AM stupider! konakat hrf

Posts.Content: konakat wrote: RANT!! Was I pissed off when I went to pick up my scan results.  First, the chest CT wasn't written up yet.  Second, the abdominal/pelvic one was but it was the sh*ttiest report I've ever seen!!  WTF!!!!  I could have written a more detailed one without even seeing the scan!  For example: Boney disease is noted - no sh*t Sherlock!!!  Details please!!!  So I ranted and raged to my nurse and McDreamy about the incompetence of the radiologist. Now for the oops: While I'm hissing and spitting, McDreamy points out that the scan says I've improved!  Huh?!? What?  Ooooooh.  Seems like I missed out on some stuff while ranting.  The scan impression said that "it was somewhat difficult to assess measurable disease in this particular case.  In comparison with the previous examination of Dec 2010, there is considered further improvement."  Only 2 lesions are visible, having shrunk from 6.3 to 3.7 and 4.8 to 4.2 cm since December.  Still have some ascites though. This explains why there wasn't as much to report - I'm getting a bit better. Silly me. Still, no bone info.  I'll get an x-ray to see if anything jumps out since my bones really hurt.  Maybe there will be more in the chest scan -- my ribs are killing me. McDreamy said he looked at the chest CT and didn't see any lesions in my lungs.  Ooooooh.  That's good. So, liver and lungs improving.  Bones to be determined.  I keep on the same chemo since it's working. Stupider me: Well, well, well, maybe the brain rads has affected my cognitive ability.  While we were discussing some chemo scheduling snafus I kept saying huh, what?  I couldn't get it though my head what McDreamy was saying.  It took 3 repetitions for me to understand something simple!!  Also he noticed that my hearing is worse too.  I'm supposed to wear hearing aids (had them for over 5 years) but I can't stand all the background noise so I rarely wear them.  How do you normal hearing people stand it?  Anyway, it's worse but it's no big deal to me, just more peace and quiet for me. So that's the latest scoop.  I should be happy but I know it won't last.  And there's still that pesky leptomenigeal mets...don't know if the rads worked until June.  I'm still grumpy and pessimistic. Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Elizabeth's Mets: Liver, bones, brain (yuck), and lungs (more yuck). Dx 5/2007, ILC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 13/19 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Rant / Oops, some good news / I AM stupider! konakat hrf

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2010 06:29PM konakat wrote: I've read women saying their TMs have been in the 800's.  I don't know much about them since they're useless for me.  Re. your stomach pain -- is it more on your right side, lower rib cage area?  If it's tender there it could be the liver mets.  My onc told me that my liver mets pain would increase during chemo -- never happened but apparently it is something that occurs.  Others have posted that their TMs have spiked when chemo was working.  I'm just throwing out some alternatives to progression.  Also, if it's definitely in the stomach area I'd assume it's the xeloda until told otherwise. In any case, worry is terrible.  If your onc isn't coming back very soon (i.e, within days), give his nurse a call and ask to speak to one of his colleagues.  Insist on it.  Please don't let yourself worry and wait.  Even if he wouldn't change something, it will help a lot just to talk to another onc and also get it documented in your chart for when your onc returns.  Hang in there Bonnie, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2010 03:50AM konakat wrote: Hi Jo -- I've had liver mets since first diagnosed.  Every onc has a order of treatments they prefer -- it's not always the same for each person.  One that I haven't included in my list is Xeloda -- it has been very good for many women here.  Here's my list and approximate timeline of the chemos I took: A/C and Taxol  (May 2007; worked) Herceptin + Tamoxifin  (recurred with liver, bones Aug 2008) Taxol (Sept 2008) Ovaries out Christmas 2008 - woohoo Taxol (Jan 2009; worked but got too toxic for me) Gemzar (May 2009; until Christmas 2009, progression) Femara (Jan 2010; while waiting for a trial I didn't get into -- first try found brain mets, 2nd try liver too bad.  Major progression everywhere, added lungs to the mix). Navelbine (didn't work, June 2010) Navelbine + Carboplatin (Aug 2010 -- working great!!) Wishing all the best for you and your sister. Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2009 10:35AM konakat wrote: I absolutely understand what you're saying lilac (BTW -- my favorite flower).  Just before I was diagnosed Stage 4 I was only hoping for a few years peace and quiet cancer-wise.  Now it never goes away.  I'm finishing up my 4th cycle of chemo, one more for luck and then hopefully hormones and herceptin only for a while.  Maybe a couple of months and then back on the chemo.  I look at people on the subway with normal lives, do they realize how lucky they are just having run-of-the-mill problems and heartbreaks. So far it's ok, chemo's part of my life now, but trying to find a job (just laid off) and knowing chemo is going to always be there is hard.  it never goes away.  I'm hoping that when it's time to stop I know, no what if I try one more time...maybe I'll get a longer break... I think while I still want to do stuff, or even just want to read an interesting book, I will keep going.  Once there aren't any pleasures in life, however small, it will be time to quit. Sorry for the ramble, but this thread topic has been on my mind a lot lately. Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2011 10:24AM konakat wrote: Hi Leanneh, I just saw your post today -- I'm very sorry about your brain mets and getting WBR.  I just finished my WBR treatments (10 zaps) on Monday.  It doesn't hurt and each session is over in a couple of minutes.  The worst side effect for me is fatigue. And I lost all my hair (it happens around day 10-14).  Initially I was told about every single possible side effect and I didn't get them (Kajsa -- you were right!) Chainsawz/Lisa told me about these site for more info.  They're great: http://brainmetsbc.org/ http://bcwatchdigest.evidencewatch.com/ I prefer the first site since it is very easy to navigate and is very current.  The second site is also very current but I got information overload from it.  Good luck with the WBR -- it is doable.  Hugs, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2011 02:55PM konakat wrote: Did I ever sleep a lot from my WBR.  It's a week past done and am still tired.  Don't worry about it -- it's just our bodies focusing on healing.  I also got dizzy a bit more than usual -- for some reason the gods were with me and both times I fell into the arms of a hottie rad tech.  A nurse told me today for the dry mouth I got from the rads, eating pineapple or mango helps -- they have a enzyme that does I don't know what.  It can be fresh or canned.  Hang in there -- it will soon be over!

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2009 05:47PM konakat wrote: I switched from Taxol/Carbo to Gemzar in May.  My scan 2 weeks ago showed only 2 lesions in my liver (as opposed to 7 in May).  Yippee!!  But my WBC and platelets have tanked and had to miss chemo this week.  Still waiting to hear if we'll tweak the Gemzar with Avastin.  Thankfully I have the appetite supression SE from Gemzar -- slowly losing weight! I have a job interview on Friday but I'm not sure I want the job -- well, it's a great job but I'm tired of Boston and my life here -- I might just pull up stakes and head home to Canada.  The comforts of home!  It's a hard decision to make.

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2011 08:21PM konakat wrote: Hi Yvonne, You're no longer long lost, you've come here.  It sure can be lonely -- friends go on with their lives and we feel left behind.  The number of times I've cried, wishing I could just have my old life back, not be cancer girl.  When we look and act OK we fit in as usual but as soon as it gets tough we can't keep up and oftentimes no one waits for us. It seems strange at first, how can you become close friends with someone you've never laid eyes on or even live half way around the world from you?  But you do, the women here are my friends.  Absolutely accepting, caring friends who understand the trials of BC and will stick with you.  I hope you stick around with us -- I would be very lonely without the women here.  And it's not just about the cancer crap, we laugh and have fun just like normal girlfriends. Lots of hugs, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2009 04:40PM konakat wrote: Hi Grace, I haven't had Cytoxan/Cyclophosphamide before -- but I'm sure you'll find others on this site that have had it.  I'm of the mind to take all the chemo offered -- why not attack the cancer with everything available.  I don't know how new Gemzar is, it is used in Canada for mets, but usually as a next step, if and when the "big guns" stop working. You might also try posting in the Canadian forums for a Canadian perspective --  there are two quite active ones called Canadian Healthcare and Calling all Canadians -- there's at least 1 woman from Winnipeg there that you might want to say hi to.  Between the 2 Cdn threads and the Stage IV forum I find all the info I'm looking for.  I hope you find them useful too! I'm sorry you're having to go through chemo again, but you'll get through it!  Elizabeth

Posts.Content: konakat wrote: Wasn't it just a few weeks ago I was celebrating shrinking liver lesions, stable lungs and healing bones?  I had asked for a brain scan, just to have it done for fun and to check up on the lesion I had -- I got the results today. Well, this sucks.  According to the report; "There has been interval development [since June 2010 scan] of numerous bilateral punctate parenchymal and leptomeningeal FLAIR hyperintensities which...[are]...worrisome for intraparanchymal and leptomeningeal metastatic disease."  In other words, there are all these teeny weeny lesions all over the surface of my brain. I also have a 8mm pineal gland cyst (apparently larger than 5mm is rare, I like being special) -- it could explain dizziness and sleep problems.  Doesn't seem to be worrisome in the report, unlike my freakin' brain!!!! I'll still have fun on my vacation last week of Jan -- and I won't worry about spending, drinking, eating, or cavorting too much.  Well, not much energy for cavorting but I'm always game for some help with the sunscreen from a sweet cabana boy...  Cripes -- do I have a spinal tap to look forward to when I get back?  Gotta get some old heavy metal to listen to.  I am going to have fun before we start a new treatment, whatever that will be.  I don't see McDreamy (onc) until Feb 1 and I hope he doesn't think to call me in earlier -- I will wait until Feb 1. So, that's the latest scoop of poop.  Blech! Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Elizabeth's Mets: Liver, bones, brain (yuck), and lungs (more yuck). Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 07:56PM - edited Jan 13, 2011 07:57PM by konakat I had a friend who would put me on the phone with her husband so he could "talk dirty" to me.  He'd describe desserts in infinitesimal detail in a slow, sultry voice.  Gee, do ya think the pre-chemo decadron has made me chatty?
Posts.Title: Just when I thought things were getting better... konakat Marple

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2011 11:13AM konakat wrote: Interestingly, I haven't had a glass of wine or any alcohol for months!  And no yellow cake with big gobs of icing flowers.  Cripes, I brought this on myself!    Champagne sounds wonderful.  Alcohol kills everything -- I should drink -- my liver's getting better and probably starved for booze!  Good plan.  My onc in Boston said cake and alcohol were good in moderation since it makes me feel good.  My onc here is a bit more of a healthy eating type so we don't discuss cake. I finally told my sister (a smart doc) -- I thought she's freak and say don't go on the vacation.  But she didn't, and she knows how stubborn I am.  It's going to be horrible telling Mom.  I keep telling her I'm going to drop dead befor reaching 50 (I'll be 49 in April, ewwwww) and she doesn't believe it.  She will now!!  I worry about having to get WBR -- I live alone and like it!  I don't want to temporarily move in with Mom or my sister.  There'd be a murder, don't know whose, but there would.  And driving!  I gotta drive!!  My sister says I look like the little blonde girl in the links I posted.  She drew some other parallels -- when I was little she called me a tasmanian devil, a la Bugs Bunny show.  Harumph! I'm loving all these posts sweet friends.  You always cheer me up!! I think I'll eat cake this weekend, and since I'm already miserable, try on my bathing suit to see how it fits.  Maybe put on my snorkel gear too to get the whole picture.  Maybe buy another suit.  Might as well go whole hog (pun intended).  And I'm not going to stress about losing those 25 pounds.  If you're over-weight don't you love those looks and people wondering, you're fat and you have cancer? Off to create mischief on the other threads.  Thanks again lovely ladies!  And gentleman Yan. Lepto Lizzie
Posts.Title: Just when I thought things were getting better... konakat Marple

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2011 01:59PM konakat wrote: Lisa -- yes, I have a rad onc -- a really nice one that likes to show pictures!  Maybe the lumbar punch/spinal tap will show nothing but I'm not holding my breath.  As much as I dread the thought, WBR might be the way to go and then sop up any leftover crap with chemo.  Been reading stuff on BCBrainMet -- love that site. It is just so weird feeling fine and this is going on.  I'm impatient to know what's next.  Wish I didn't get the report but couldn't help myself, especially since I didn't expect anything wrong.  Argh.  Curiosity kills the cat kinda of thing... Horrid saying but it fits.

Posts.Title: Just when I thought things were getting better... konakat Marple

Posts.Content: konakat wrote: Wasn't it just a few weeks ago I was celebrating shrinking liver lesions, stable lungs and healing bones?  I had asked for a brain scan, just to have it done for fun and to check up on the lesion I had -- I got the results today. Well, this sucks.  According to the report; "There has been interval development [since June 2010 scan] of numerous bilateral punctate parenchymal and leptomeningeal FLAIR hyperintensities which...[are]...worrisome for intraparanchymal and leptomeningeal metastatic disease."  In other words, there are all these teeny weeny lesions all over the surface of my brain. I also have a 8mm pineal gland cyst (apparently larger than 5mm is rare, I like being special) -- it could explain dizziness and sleep problems.  Doesn't seem to be worrisome in the report, unlike my freakin' brain!!!! I'll still have fun on my vacation last week of Jan -- and I won't worry about spending, drinking, eating, or cavorting too much.  Well, not much energy for cavorting but I'm always game for some help with the sunscreen from a sweet cabana boy...  Cripes -- do I have a spinal tap to look forward to when I get back?  Gotta get some old heavy metal to listen to.  I am going to have fun before we start a new treatment, whatever that will be.  I don't see McDreamy (onc) until Feb 1 and I hope he doesn't think to call me in earlier -- I will wait until Feb 1. So, that's the latest scoop of poop.  Blech! Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Elizabeth's Mets: Liver, bones, brain (yuck), and lungs (more yuck). Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2009 09:39AM konakat wrote: Hi Grace -- Sorry about the news.  I have mets to my liver and bones.  No more surgery -- as far as I know, mets are handled with chemo and biologics for most women.  To treat my liver mets I was put on Taxol (again) and Herceptin.  When taxol stopped working I started Gemzar and have good results and it's much easier to tolerate! Since I'm moving back to Canada, I'm particularly interested in what other Canadian Stage IV women have for chemo - as far as I know the protocols are the same.  I'm so sorry about your mets, but it's doable, but still sucks.  Let us know what your treatment plan will be.  Hugs, Elizabeth

Hope you have a wonderful Friday too! Elizabeth xox

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2009 06:54AM konakat wrote: My cat is my baby and we both have our trials and tribulations.  I have chemo and she gets 150cc's of ringers fluid 3 times a week for her kidney disease.  It's not hard to give to her, just jab a huge needle under the scruff of her neck.  The big blob of fluid under her neck and shoulders makes her look like she's on steriods and all pumped up with muscle until it soaks into her system.  I discovered the value of hats when I lived in Edmonton Alberta for 4 years!  So cold that the snow squeaked underfoot.  Way back in the 80s I went through my Princess Diana phase and wore hats a lot.  Now it's mostly just to keep warm.

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2009 09:25AM - edited Aug 9, 2009 09:27AM by konakat AlaskaAngel wrote: Chemotherapy has a pretty low success rate for a few in either preventing recurrence altogether or delaying death...The small percentage who actually do benefit from toxic therapy are that small group who win the lottery. The small percentage who actually do benefit from toxic therapy are that small group who win the lottery. You've got to be kidding!!!!  The majority of Stage IV women, and other stages, are alive because of chemo.  Yeah, right, we'd all be better off to let our cancer spread and grow.  Give me a break!!  Stage 1, depending on your prognosis you may not need chemo.  Anything else, you're taking an awful risk if you don't treat with chemo.  It only takes one cancer cell...
Posts.Title: How many here have survived 6 years after chemo? gscott Beatis

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2009 03:29PM konakat wrote: It's OK GScott -- just take a deep breath and get through Monday.  There's just so much bad information, misleading information, and unfortunately horrible people out their that prey on the sick and promise them miracles only to make a few bucks. Read the Alternative posts, but also look at the other forums, see women that are living because they did chemo.  Sure it sucks, but it has kept many of us alive and having good lives.  Many have cancer-free lives after chemo! Just be cautious on what you read, who you listen too.  Make sure they're reputable.  And then you can do what's best for you.  As I said on another thread, check the Stage IV thread and see a lot of women that are surviving, and living well. Best of luck Monday -- I hope you are well. ELizabeth
Posts.Title: How many here have survived 6 years after chemo? gscott Beatis

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2009 03:42PM konakat wrote: I'll look around for you (I have a research/library background so I love doing that!) and post what I find.  One little interesting tidbit for you: My mom had breast cancer 15 years ago, had a lumpectomy and radiation, no chemo.  And she's alive and kicking at 84.  When I was first diagnosed at 45 I was hoping to have the same treatment, but my breast cancer was very different from her's and had to have chemo.  Just an example of one size doesn't fit all.

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2009 12:42AM - edited Dec 10, 2009 12:45AM by konakat I agree that you need to push for another chemo.  Ask him which ones are available and what he recommends. Tell him you want those liver lesions gone!  Tell him you want an aggressive treatment.  This is crazy that you're getting nightmares.  If he doesn't answer your questions to your satisfaction consider seeing another oncologist.  Also talk to the social worker, she/he could go to bat for you and pave the way.  You deserve to feel better, physically and emotionally.  Let us know what happens.  Hugs, Elizabeth xox Edit to add:  Since your liver is doing these funky things, perhaps a consultation with a liver expert might be a good idea? Also, if you have a favourite nurse, talk to her about your concerns.  She/he might also help get things done for you.

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2009 10:39PM konakat wrote: Hi Brad, I too had one suspicious lesion on my liver that disappeared after chemo.  It was a 99% certainty that it was mets because it did disappear with the chemo (a normal cyst would have stayed around).  It was very small and in a very difficult spot to biopsy so it was never done.  When I had a PET after a year my liver lit up again, confirming that it was definitely Stage IV right from initial diagnosis. Posts.Content: konakat wrote: I've had considerable scarring after my lumpectomy and margins cleanup and have fibroids from the radiation.  To deal with this, my surgeon recommended a type of physical therapy called "endermological massage - LPG".  It's some sort of machine that kneads the skin and loosens everything up.  It's also used for treating cellulite.  And fibromyalgia.  Hmmmm.  Apparently it can work so well for fibroids caused by radiation that in some cases cosmetic and reconstruction surgery can be avoided. Has anyone had some experience with this?  I can't find much/any information on this treatment. Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2008 05:46PM konakat wrote: I have an update on this -- This treatment uses a machine that does deep tissue massage, in reverse.  Instead of kneading in, it pulls out using suction and massage.  I've had 3 treatments so far and have noticed a difference in my breast shape, for the better.  Apparently other patients of my surgeon have been pleased so I hope it will get me in decent shape.

Tried on my bathing suits last night/this morning at 3AM.  Not hideous in the dim light.  Happily I lost 6 pounds without trying -- must be the cookies I ate for 3 days (the Chips Ahoy Chocolate Chip Cookie Diet).  I'll still have some shopping therapy next week just for fun, not that there's much summer stuff out yet.  And a pedicure!!!
Posts.Title: Just when I thought things were getting better... konakat Marple

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2011 04:04PM konakat wrote: When I first got the scan I glanced to the Impressions Section and the word "leptomeningeal" jumped out at me -- almost heard this Hitchcockian violin music for surprises -  wwwaaaa, waaaaa, waaaaaa. I expected a boring report, nothing more. I had absolutely no concerns or worries. I only wanted a complete set of end-of-year/new-year scans.  Whimpered all the way out of the hospital to home. Thought of HeidiHo and CarynRose. Searched this site and BrainMetsBC like crazy. Googled words I didn't know. Thought it could be a mistake and how embarrassed I will be if I posted the news and it was wrong. I still think that.  So there I am.  I can't/won't acknowledge it completely until I get a confirmation test.  It's only "worrisome", not definite until the lumber puncture.  It's gotta be wrong.  Right?  Maybe?  Well, it could be. On a lighter, slightly twisted note, I mentioned to my sister about me possibly, temporarily (I hope not) moving in with her and who will murder whom first.  She said she reads mysteries and could get away with the murder.  Yeah, right, she reads fluffy old lady mysteries.  What's she going to do, hide me with a tea cozy?  I told her I read forensic science thrillers so I'd get away with it.  Who'd suspect a poor cancer patient?  She's a social activist and, well, who knows what they're all about?

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 03:31PM konakat wrote: Well here's the scoop: About the brain lesions, McDreamy says there's a tiny possibility that they could be due to the radiation I had last spring and nothing to worry about (I assume he means necrosis like Frankie and Chainsawz discussed elsewhere).  But, for me, I don't believe it since there are tiny blips everywhere, not just by my original lesion.  So, I will have chemo as usual this week and next.  In 3 weeks I'll get MRIs of my brain and everything else.  McDreamykins will meet with my radiation oncologist (no nickname yet) and see what's what.  If it is indeed lesions, I'll get 2 lumbar punches (spinal taps) to confirm and see how bad it is and also get whole brain radiation.  Hopefully that will work (you can only radiate your whole brain once).  It will leave me bald as a cue ball. But I look kinda cute bald and still have my wigs.  I won't tell Mom until I have something definitive to tell her. Of course Boston guy tried to cheer me up.  He said I'd save on electricity with my glow-in-the-dark head.  He wondered what he'd hold on to since I won't get my hair back. I suggested my ears (I may not have found a cabana boy, but I still have Boston boy!).  Teehee!  He can always make me laugh. McDreamylovemuffin mentioned discussing DNR etc with my family.  I told him I did already.  If you can bring me back normal, do it.  If I'll be a drooling vegetable, put the pillow over my face. It gave him a good laugh and got me a nice hug.  He said he'd do everything he can since he like having me around.  I told him I call him McDreamy and kinda like him too.  So another 3-4 weeks to get definitive news.  I hate waiting!!!!
Posts.Title: Just when I thought things were getting better... konakat Marple

Posts.Content: konakat wrote: Wasn't it just a few weeks ago I was celebrating shrinking liver lesions, stable lungs and healing bones?  I had asked for a brain scan, just to have it done for fun and to check up on the lesion I had -- I got the results today. Well, this sucks.  According to the report; "There has been interval development [since June 2010 scan] of numerous bilateral punctate parenchymal and leptomeningeal FLAIR hyperintensities which...[are]...worrisome for intraparanchymal and leptomeningeal metastatic disease."  In other words, there are all these teeny weeny lesions all over the surface of my brain. I also have a 8mm pineal gland cyst (apparently larger than 5mm is rare, I like being special) -- it could explain dizziness and sleep problems.  Doesn't seem to be worrisome in the report, unlike my freakin' brain!!!! I'll still have fun on my vacation last week of Jan -- and I won't worry about spending, drinking, eating, or cavorting too much.  Well, not much energy for cavorting but I'm always game for some help with the sunscreen from a sweet cabana boy...  Cripes -- do I have a spinal tap to look forward to when I get back?  Gotta get some old heavy metal to listen to.  I am going to have fun before we start a new treatment, whatever that will be.  I don't see McDreamy (onc) until Feb 1 and I hope he doesn't think to call me in earlier -- I will wait until Feb 1. So, that's the latest scoop of poop.  Blech! Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Elizabeth's Mets: Liver, bones, brain (yuck), and lungs (more yuck). My previous ex wants me to visit him in SF - he's a smart, gorgeous, hot Serb with a sexy accent.  Funny thing about him is that he gets along better with both his ex-wives and me (ex-girlfriend) than when we were together.  Hopefully this spring I'll make it to SF -- I want to visit Sonoma and Napa Valley again too. Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2011 08:21AM konakat wrote: Bah.  Even the chocolate isn't cheering me up these days.  Oh, speaking of chocolate -- I got my usual post-chemo chocolate bar Thursday, even though I skipped chemo, and half of it fell on the floor.  The three second rule doesn't work in hospitals.  So I threw it away.  What's funny is that it was an O Henry -- probably looks like a piece of poo in the garbage can! I'm still having trouble sleeping -- I think of Chloe (cat - died almost 4 months ago) and my eyes snap open.  I always said I just wanted to outlive my cats and Mom (Mom will outlive me now) and now that I don't have my kitties I have nothing.  What's the point?  Just existing.  Then I get on about how nobody loved me enough to want to stay with me.  What's wrong with me or is it just my horrible taste in men?  Blah again.  I've had fun, but looking back I could have done things a lot better.  I want my old life back. :-((((

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 02:46PM - edited Feb 23, 2011 02:51PM by konakat I think I was stressed going to pick up my scan report -- I left the keys in the car with the car running!  Went grocery shopping afterwards -- didn't get cake, chocolate, cookies, or ice cream.  For some reason I got half of a watermelon.  And lo-cal sorbet, orange flavour.  Hmmmm, not thinking straight?  Or at least as I normally do? Soooooo, here's scoop.  I learnt a new word today -- sulcus.  This is the valley of the brain's wiggly shapes.  The hill is called the gryus.  I have a bunch of lesions in my sulci (that sounds rude, or like an STD) in the right frontal region, left occipital region, and right frontal sulci.  The right frontal ones are larger than seen in Jan.  There are fewer lesions than what showed in the Jan MRI but they write this off as that it used a different MRI technique (it was dust on the lens!!  Hahahaaa).  But there's more!!  All of my spine has lesions (no surprise there).  And, the marrow between C2 and C3 has mets too.  This is new.  In summary:  There are multiple enhancing lesions involving the leptomeniges of the cerebral hemisphere in keeping with leptomeningeal carcinomatosis.  Extensive bony mets to spine. I'm quite calm about this -- it'll probably sink in when I see McDreamykins. I guess a lumbar punch is in the cards.  Once I know everything I'll tell Mum.  Now that will be a treat.  Poor Mum, I hate making her sad. And thank-you for all the warm thoughts and wishes -- it really helps knowing that you are here.  Love, Elizabeth

I'll still have fun on my vacation last week of Jan -- and I won't worry about spending, drinking, eating, or cavorting too much.  Well, not much energy for cavorting but I'm always game for some help with the sunscreen from a sweet cabana boy...  Cripes -- do I have a spinal tap to look forward to when I get back?  Gotta get some old heavy metal to listen to.  I am going to have fun before we start a new treatment, whatever that will be.  I don't see McDreamy (onc) until Feb 1 and I hope he doesn't think to call me in earlier -- I will wait until Feb 1. So, that's the latest scoop of poop.  Blech! Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Elizabeth's Mets: Liver, bones, brain (yuck), and lungs (more yuck). Posts.Content: May 9, 2010 12:19PM konakat wrote: Hi Louise, There's a forum for Canadian Breast Cancer Survivors (go to the list of Forums and it's towards the bottom of the list) with 2 active theads -- Calling all Canadians and Canadian Healthcare.  Lots of women (and a delightful husband, Yan) from the Toronto area to connect with.  I was first treated in the US (lived in Boston for 3 years) then moved back home to Ottawa in December.  The chemo I've gotten in the US is available in Canada.  It does take a while longer to get chemos approved in Canada though, however most of the main ones (taxol, taxotere, xeloda, tykerb, etc and the hormonals) are available.  There are also the international clinical trials available too -- I'm waiting to go on one.  Being in Toronto is as good as anywhere else in the world. I've also heard of a great support group/organization on Toronto -- Willow -- http:///www.willow.org  In the subject of support -- the GTA ladies had just had a get-together last month and are planning one late summer in Niagra-on-the-lake.  I hope to get down to the Toronto area to meet these women -- they've been wonderful.  I'll bump up the Canadian healthcare thread to the top of the forum for you. Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2010 11:12PM konakat wrote: Hi Dee, I'm very sorry about your friend.  Obviously we all have at least one of these areas with mets since we're stage IV.  I have mets in my liver, bones, brain, and lungs -- the 4 most common areas to get mets from BC.  Some of her treatment will depend on her estrogen receptor status and on her Her2 status -- there are various meds for women that have positive for one or both.  There are also many chemos available to try.  If one doesn't work you move to the next one on the list.  Sometimes bone mets are radiated. Prognosis is a tricky one -- you just don't know.  It could be 1 day or 50 years.  Statistics say that there is a 20% chance of living 5 years.  I'm soon hitting year 4 and still going. Your friend's oncologist will come up with a treatment plan for her and do regular bloodwork and scans to monitor her progress.  It can be a rough road at times but there are many women here leading full lives, even working fulltime.  Wishing your friend and you all the best, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2011 02:29PM konakat wrote: Well, that was fun.  I forgot how delicious my rad onc was.  He's from France and has the most wonderful accent -- I was melting -- hope it didn't get to hot and humid for those riding in my pocket!  His official nickname is Dr. Delish. I don't have to get a lumbar puncture since the MRI confirms the leptomenigeal mets.  I will get 10 WBR zaps starting in 1-2 weeks.  I managed to keep a straight face and told him I wanted him to do me as soon as possible.    Gawd, I just wanted to throw him on the examination table and have my way with him.  OK, back to serious stuff...  He says it's too risky to zap my spinal column since I've had so much chemo and my bone marrow is already crap (i.e., low platelets, etc.).  The WBR will take care of everything. SEs include hair falling out (may or may not grow back in), loss of some memory, loss of some cognition, maybe a stumbling gait (I can join Monty Python's Ministry of Silly Walks!).  These SEs will develop slowly, even after the rads is complete.  I may not be able to drive again (F*CK!!!!!!!!!!!).  I asked Dr Delish if he'd buy my car and he said no.  Dr. McDreamykins was on holiday so I saw another doc.  It was just chit-chat -- cancel my chemo and zometa until after the rads.  Schedule my port flush instead.  See him in 4 weeks. I told Mom -- she handled it well but does wonder how I'll get out to visit her -- I'll figure that out later.  When I was being told about the SEs all I could think was that I will become Mom.  Mom and I joked that we will sit around the kitchen table, both asking the same question or telling the same story over and over again.  I was too chicken and kinda forgot to ask about my prognosis.  I know it's grim but I want to know what they think.  Who knows, maybe I'll fool them like I did last summer and stick around for a while. I'm not really upset, maybe in shock?  But I'm counting on cracking myself up as I become goofy.  I should start a new thread when I start the rads to observe my slow decline.  Aren't I morbid?  So, that's it. Thank-you again for sticking by my side.  It means so very much to me.
Posts.Title: Just when I thought things were getting better... konakat Marple

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2011 09:59AM - edited Mar 7, 2011 10:00AM by konakat I re-use the same mask.  It's horrible.  I wanted to keep it the first time (for halloween) and the tech said they hang onto to them.  At least it's a quick zap, not a 15 minute one like last time. Mom gave me cab fare for the 2 weeks.  I hope I don't have to give up driving for very long.  Mom lives out in the country so it will be cab, bus, cab to get to her place. This is a major pain in the patoutie, but the alternative (no rads) is a wee bit worse.  Still looking forward to getting goofy.  Hours of laughs for all!  But then, maybe I won't since my lesions are teeny and haven't taken over masses of my noggin.

Well, this sucks.  According to the report; "There has been interval development [since June 2010 scan] of numerous bilateral punctate parenchymal and leptomeningeal FLAIR hyperintensities which...[are]...worrisome for intraparanchymal and leptomeningeal metastatic disease."  In other words, there are all these teeny weeny lesions all over the surface of my brain. I also have a 8mm pineal gland cyst (apparently larger than 5mm is rare, I like being special) -- it could explain dizziness and sleep problems.  Doesn't seem to be worrisome in the report, unlike my freakin' brain!!!! I'll still have fun on my vacation last week of Jan -- and I won't worry about spending, drinking, eating, or cavorting too much.  Well, not much energy for cavorting but I'm always game for some help with the sunscreen from a sweet cabana boy...  Cripes -- do I have a spinal tap to look forward to when I get back?  Gotta get some old heavy metal to listen to.  I am going to have fun before we start a new treatment, whatever that will be.  I don't see McDreamy (onc) until Feb 1 and I hope he doesn't think to call me in earlier -- I will wait until Feb 1. So, that's the latest scoop of poop.  Blech! Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Elizabeth's Mets: Liver, bones, brain (yuck), and lungs (more yuck). Dx 5/2007, ILC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 13/19 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: May 8, 2009 07:45PM konakat wrote: I am leaning towards the infection, not cancer.  I know it's hard to do, but you need to get on the phone once or twice a day to the doctor's office.  Or head to a clinic this weekend, tonight!!  I've had problems getting an appt for a bad cold/bronchitis -- the appt takers just don't have any medical training - it's not their fault, it's just what is. I had to repeat over and over that I was on chemo and my immune system was compromised to get in the next day. And as someone else said, never consider you're a bother -- we're here for you!!  And let us know what happens, how you are.

Posts.Content: May 8, 2010 02:42PM konakat wrote: Hi Weeze (I call my sister that!) -- I know what a terrible shock it can be.  I felt fine and was diagnosed with breast cancer and mets to my liver 3 years ago.  There is lots that can be done for your Mom so she can continue to live a good life for years.  I don't know what her doctor meant by "if we proceed with treatment" -- maybe he's just leaving the door wide open for your Mom to decide what she wants to do.  Your Mom should just say, tell me how we're going to fight this and find out the options.  If she is not satisfied with what she's hearing or the oncologist's attitude go to another oncologist.  Wishing you and your Mom all the best, Elizabeth
Posts.Title: Terrified for my Mom Weeze010101 chainsawz

Posts.Content: May 8, 2010 07:41PM konakat wrote: It is no surprise that your Mom has less energy and may be depressed. The news has affected you so much, imagine the turmoil your Mom must feel.  She's also probably trying to keep it together so you don't worry to much.  It always seems like a whirlwind when you're diagnosed, a crazy rollercoaster ride with all the tests and appointments -- it takes a while to get your breath.  Take your cues from your Mom on what she needs.  Just be there to help -- whether with appointments or stuff around the house.  Or let her be.  Right now focus on getting her set up with the treatment she wants.  The hospital also has a social worker if she needs some extra support and also a dietician she can consult for nutrition and to make sure any supplements she takes don't interfere with her treatment.   If she's on the internet you can always send her here -- we'd love to meet her online and help out any way we can. Take care and do have a Happy Mother's Day, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2011 05:21PM konakat wrote: Barbe -- you're a wild woman! I would have been nervous if the rays didn't show up!  There was flourescence in the water so if you flapped your arms around it sparkled.  A moray eel slithered around me to the light we had going to get the manta rays and plankton to visit.  That was creepy. I remember snorkling in the Great Barrier Reef.  The first time I saw a shark dozing on the bottom I freaked.  The next times someone yelled shark I went to see.  One evening (we spent 4 nights there over New Years!) the captain tossed some fish food pellets into the water and there was a feeding frenzy of sharks.  The next night was a night dive and you couldn't pay me enough to get in the water! I'll stick to the daytime thank-you.  I'm scared of mackos and tiger sharks.  Apparently Great Whites just take a taste and usually spit you out. I was amazed that the past couple of years about 5 great whites were tagged near Cape Cod.  Still went swimming -- I was hoping they'd be more attracted to the splashing kids.  That's my dream -- a cage dive with great whites.  I probably have so many chemicals seeping through my pores that it's a shark deterrent.

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2010 01:48PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 05:57AM by konakat Hi Stephanie -- I am very sorry about your BIL and your Mom.  A lot of sad and bad stuff going on.  That one chemo works for some people and not for others happens quite a bit.  Edit:  If it is more cancer (which I hope not), odds are that it is BC that has spread, not a new primary.  BC does mutate in that it becomes resistant to a chemo over time, but it is still BC.  It's happened to me (and most Stage IV women) where chemos worked well for a while and then the cancer starts to grow again.  It is devastating if a chemo stops working. We have our hopes pinned on each chemo we try. There are more chemos that you can try if you get bad news.  Also, since you're in Kingston (and close to Ottawa, Toronto) you are close to quite a few research hospitals.  Ask your onc about clinical trials. You've had a lot of sadness in your life lately.  It's no surprise that it's taking longer than usual to pick yourself up again.  You will when the time is right.  And you and your onc will come up with a new plan to kick BC's butt. Edit:  Oooh, just re-read my post -- I'm not saying that you have more BC, but if it is, it probably won't be a new primary.  Let's hope for some good news!! Gentle hugs, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: konakat wrote: Wasn't it just a few weeks ago I was celebrating shrinking liver lesions, stable lungs and healing bones?  I had asked for a brain scan, just to have it done for fun and to check up on the lesion I had -- I got the results today. Well, this sucks.  According to the report; "There has been interval development [since June 2010 scan] of numerous bilateral punctate parenchymal and leptomeningeal FLAIR hyperintensities which...[are]...worrisome for intraparanchymal and leptomeningeal metastatic disease."  In other words, there are all these teeny weeny lesions all over the surface of my brain. I also have a 8mm pineal gland cyst (apparently larger than 5mm is rare, I like being special) -- it could explain dizziness and sleep problems.  Doesn't seem to be worrisome in the report, unlike my freakin' brain!!!! I'll still have fun on my vacation last week of Jan -- and I won't worry about spending, drinking, eating, or cavorting too much.  Well, not much energy for cavorting but I'm always game for some help with the sunscreen from a sweet cabana boy...  Cripes -- do I have a spinal tap to look forward to when I get back?  Gotta get some old heavy metal to listen to.  I am going to have fun before we start a new treatment, whatever that will be.  I don't see McDreamy (onc) until Feb 1 and I hope he doesn't think to call me in earlier -- I will wait until Feb 1. So, that's the latest scoop of poop.  Blech! Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Elizabeth's Mets: Liver, bones, brain (yuck), and lungs (more yuck). Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2011 12:27PM - edited Mar 2, 2011 12:28PM by konakat Back to our previously scheduled program...  And of course, I thank-you for your kind thoughts.  Now where were we... Lisa -- I'll check out those websites and look for the person you mentioned. Yan -- my rad onc says he does either 5 day or 10 day zaps but prefers 10 day zaps (maybe we're all weenies here in Ottawa).  He wants to use a lower dose for a longer time to be gentler. Hmmm.  Olga's onc must think she has a strong consitution and will best be served with the 5 days.  Maybe my deer-caught-in-the-headlights expression made him want to play it safe! I'm also going to ask him about driving.  I remember our dear LisaSDCA could drive after a few months time too.  I stopped for a few weeks last year to play it safe.  I don't want to drive if I shouldn't/can't.  Athena, etc -- I like to know my prognosis, especially if it's awful.  Then I feel so good when I beat it.  If it comes true it won't be such a shock.  If it doesn't I can wear a smirk around the hospital, feeling all special.  It doesn't make me give up or anything, it gets me competitive!  Sort of like, oh yeah?  You think I'm gonna kick the bucket?  Just watch and see... It is just so strange that I don't feel sick!  Since I'm curious like a cat I'm actually looking forward to the WBR to see what it's like.  Unfortunately if I don't like it tough beans for me! Off to surf around the boards.  I'll try not to create a ruckus for a while.  But if my brain goes wonky this month, well....  Love you all, Elizabeth Edit:  I'm gonna tell him about driving, not ask!  Really, if I'm OK...we'll see...but I won't if I can't.

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2011 07:38PM konakat wrote: Hi Fatima, I was on Gemzar and Carboplatin and I did get some liver tumour shrinkage, but it was slow.  And eventually stopped working.  Herceptin stopped working for me early in my diagnosis too.  The latest combination I've been on for about 9 months is Navelbine (Vinorelbine) and Carboplatin and it is working in my liver (tumours shrinking).  It's been my best chemo so far for results in my liver. Your liver lesions could be benign since you haven't seen any shrinkage -- maybe you can get a biopsy on them? I got neuropathy from Taxol and Navelbine but considering that the chemo is keeping me alive, I'll take the neuropathy.  I hope this helps, Elizabeth

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2007 07:33AM - edited Oct 5, 2007 07:36AM by konakat Background: My treatment is 4 A/C and 4 Taxol, then radiation (also herpcepin and tamoxofin).  I am 45, found lump by self-exam in April 2007, largish ductal tumor and lots of nodes, I had a lumpectomy and after the A/C I had another surgery to clear my margins.  Re. chemotheraphy -- at first I had the common reaction -- do I have to? (thinking about my hair loss, feeling ill).  Yes, it is traumatic -- but your hair feels soooooo good coming in all soft and new.  Mine started growing when I took the break for the 2nd surgery and keeps on growing during my Taxol.  Thank god skipping chemo was a passing thought -- go for the chemo!  Go for anything they offer.  It's your arsenal to beat the disease!!  Once your treatment is scheduled you will feel more in control and empowered. If you want to work through the treatments, which I have done, I have 2 suggestions.  I got chemo on Friday, rested on the weekend and took the Monday off -- the worst side effects seem to happen on days 3-4.  I felt a bit queasy on the Tues and Wed, but by Thursday I was back to normal.  Another idea, which I wish I had done -- and is good if you want to take the minimum of days off.  Have chemo on the Wed and the worst days you can handle over the weekend. AND, make sure your oncologist and nurses know exactly how you are feeling -- there are excellent drugs to combat the side effects.  Don't be shy -- they want to know and help you get through this!! When your treatment first starts it seems soooo long -- but once you start x-ing off the days it goes pretty fast.  To help pass the time getting the chemo I sit in the non-TV room -- it's nice to chat with the others there.  Also, these breastcancer.org groups are great -- keep coming back -- the women here have really helped me. Also, see about doing the American Cancer Society's Look Good Feel Better course -- your oncologist or nurse can tell you how to do this.  The evening is a blast -- very fun and you get tons of excellent makeup to take home!! I wish every new patient and soon-to-be-cancer-suvivor all the best.  This is all about you -- take every opportunity to do things for yourself -- take every offer of help -- once you are feeling better you can give your thanks in turn.   I've never been a joiner of support groups, I've only looked at these boards and have drawn a lot of strength and encouragement. Best wishes Elizabeth

I had a bone density test last week and to my absolute surprise I have osteopenia.  I am not petite/small boned.  I'm "only" 47, postmenopausal since getting my ovaries out last December.  I drink 1-2 glasses of milk a day.  I've been getting Zometa every month for about a year.  I had 1 met on my spine but it has been gone for ages (not that it's related, just background info). So, WTF!!  Apparently it has been brought on by all the chemo (now into 13th straight month). Have others had a similar experience?  What are you doing about it?  Is there anything that can be done?  Does this increase the risk for my mets returning to my bones?  The big plan is to hopefully get rid of the last stubborn lesion on my liver and then switch to AIs -- more risk for osteopenia. Thanks for any advice, sharing of experience. Elizabeth Edit:  Arrrgh -- typo in the topic line.  Chemo brain -- and I stand by that reason for my typos! Elizabeth's Mantra: When in doubt, eat cake. When you haven't a clue, add ice cream. Elizabeth's Mets: Liver, bones, brain (yuck), and lungs (more yuck). Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2009 06:34AM konakat wrote: Hi Kirby -- I am so sorry that this has happened to you.  The questions I would ask are what are the treatment options and how long you will be receiving the treatments.  And when you will get your next scan/test to determine how the treatment is doing.  Sometimes chemo can go on for several months so I like to know when the next scan is, to chunk up the time, to have some milestones, so it is easier to manage in my mind.  And, take notes -- it's a lot of info to digest.  And ask questions, and if you think of something after the appointment, don't be shy to call back and ask.  And of course, the Stage IV board has lots of info, please ask us anything -- we're here to help.  Big hugs, Elizabeth
Posts.Title: Am I Stage IV now? kirby happytobealive

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2009 01:05AM - edited Sep 2, 2009 01:09AM by konakat HI Kirby -- I have 7 mets on my liver (and one on my spine).  They range in size up to 2 cm.  I was put on taxol -- 3 weeks on, 1 week off -- plus zometa (for bones), carboplatin and herceptin.  Since the taxol was a lower dose my hair only thinned, which was nice.  I still took the scissors to it to even it up and make the thinning less apparent.  After 6 months on taxol it started to get to toxic for me (dizzy, high BP) and was taken off it, even though I was improving.  I was switched to Gemzar (with Herceptin and Zometa still) and here we are today.  I may be geting my chemo cocktail re-formulated tomorrow -- geting the results of my PET scan. I've seen quite a few women here who are stable with liver mets, and have been so for many years -- so it's not all doom and gloom.  I never did get my liver biopsied -- since I was Stage IV from the get-go it was assumed that it was the same as my breast tumor.  Also, the tumor was in a very inaccessible place so we skipped it. So hang in there -- the treatments are do-able and not all of them cause you to lose your hair.  :-)  Let us know how the biopsy goes, and what your treatment will be.  We're here to cheer you on!! Elizabeth xoxoo

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2011 08:01PM konakat wrote: Hi Jenn, I live alone too and I am not willing to give up my independence until I decide I must.  I've had some very difficult times but as long as I can struggle to the grocery store and dial for pizza I'm staying put.  I've cabbed it to chemo instead of taking up an offer for a lift. I may be extreme in my thinking, but cancer has taken so much from me I loathe it taking my independence too. My sister often offers to do stuff for me but I refuse.  Don't make me an invalid before my time. I know that isn't her intent, it's just me being stubborn.  I worry that if I become dependent on others before I really need to I will just grow weaker and whither away.  Then again, I recognize that others may thrive with the help.  There's no set answer. I know the time will come that I can't do it on my own but I will not become dependent until I can no longer take care of myself.  Maybe I'm wrong to be so stubborn about getting help, but I can't help it.  I do believe that you, I, all of us will just know when the time is right.
